• It was a bold move on their part to open a business in France.
    • ;
  • The wine made him bold enough to approach her.
    • ;
  • a bold and fearless warrior

column5: an occasion when a bomb is dropped or left somewhere; the act of doing this
column10:
• recent bombings in major cities
    • ;
  • The neighbourhood was badly damaged by enemy bombing.

column5: an extra amount of money that is added to a payment, especially to somebody’s wages or salary as a reward
column10:
• a £100 Christmas bonus
    • ;
  • productivity bonuses
    • ;
  • the row over bankers' bonuses
    • ;
  • What is actually paid will depend on the bonus payments made at the end of the policy.

column5: an arrangement that you make in advance to buy a ticket to travel somewhere, go to the theatre, etc.
column10:
• a booking form/hall/clerk
    • ;
  • Can I make a booking for Friday?
    • ;
  • Early booking is recommended.
    • ;
  • No advance booking is necessary.
    • ;
  • We can't take any more bookings.

column5: a sudden increase in trade and economic activity; a period of wealth and success
column10:
• Living standards improved rapidly during the post-war boom.
    • ;
  • boom in something a boom in car sales
    • ;
  • a boom year (for trade, exports, etc.)
    • ;
  • a property/housing boom

column5: something that helps or encourages somebody/something
column10:
• a great/tremendous/welcome boost
    • ;
  • The tax cuts will give a much needed boost to the economy.
    • ;
  • Winning the competition was a wonderful boost for her morale.

column5: to make something increase, or become better or more successful
column10:
• to boost exports/profits
    • ;
  • to boost productivity/spending
    • ;
  • The movie helped boost her screen career.
    • ;
  • to boost somebody’s confidence/morale
    • ;
  • Getting that job did a lot to boost his ego (= make him feel more confident).

column5: if something bounces or you bounce it, it moves quickly away from a surface it has just hit or you make it do this
column10:
• The ball bounced twice before he could reach it.
    • ;
  • bounce off something Short sound waves bounce off even small objects.
    • ;
  • The light bounced off the river and dazzled her.
    • ;
  • + adv./prep. The ball bounced high and she missed it.
    • ;
  • bounce something (against/on/off something) She bounced the ball against the wall.

column5: certain or likely to happen, or to do or be something
column10:
• There are bound to be changes when the new system is introduced.
    • ;
  • It's bound to be sunny again tomorrow.
    • ;
  • You've done so much work—you're bound to pass the exam.
    • ;
  • It was bound to happen sooner or later (= we should have expected it).
    • ;
  • These problems were almost bound to arise.
    • ;
  • You're bound to be nervous the first time (= it's easy to understand).

column5: a real or imagined line that marks the limits or edges of something and separates it from other things or places; a dividing line
column10:
• After the war the national boundaries were redrawn.

  • (British English) county boundaries

  • boundary changes/disputes
    • ;
  • The fence marks the boundary between my property and hers.
    • ;
  • Scientists continue to push back the boundaries of human knowledge.
    • ;
  • It is up to the teacher to set the boundary between acceptable and unacceptable behaviour.
    • ;
  • He could just see her beyond the boundary wall of the cemetery.
    • ;
  • to extend the boundaries of high art to include some popular music

column5: the act of bending your head or the upper part of your body forward in order to say hello or goodbye to somebody or to show respect
column10:
• She gave a slight bow of her head in greeting.
    • ;
  • The messenger made a formal bow and left the room.

column5: to move your head or the top half of your body forwards and downwards as a sign of respect or to say hello or goodbye
column10:
• bow (to/before somebody/something) He bowed low to the assembled crowd.
    • ;
  • bow down (to/before somebody/something) The people all bowed down before the emperor.

column5: a failure to do something that must be done by law

• a breach of contract/copyright/warranty
    • ;
  • They are in breach of Article 119.
    • ;
  • (British English) (a) breach of the peace (= the crime of behaving in a noisy or violent way in public)
    • ;
  • Selling goods constituted a breach of regulation 10B.

column5: to not keep to an agreement or not keep a promise
column10:
• The government is accused of breaching the terms of the treaty.
    • ;
  • A doctor was sacked for allegedly breaching patient confidentiality.
    • ;
  • The proposed changes breached trade union rules.

column5: an occasion when a vehicle or machine stops working

• a breakdown on the motorway
    • ;
  • a breakdown recovery service
    • ;
  • Most breakdown services give priority to women travelling alone.

  • The national breakdown organizations are on hand to help motorists 24 hours a day.

column5: an important development that may lead to an agreement or achievement

    • ;
  • a significant breakthrough in negotiations

  • a major breakthrough in cancer research

column5: a particular type of animal that has been developed by people in a certain way, especially a type of dog, cat or farm animal

• Labradors and other large breeds of dog

  • a breed of cattle/sheep

column5: to have sex and produce young
column10: • Many animals breed only at certain times of the year.

column5: baked clay used for building walls, houses and other buildings; an individual block of this

• The school is built of brick.
    • ;
  • a pile of bricks
    • ;
  • a brick wall

column5: for a short time

• He had spoken to Emma only briefly.
    • ;
  • She met John briefly on Friday night.

column5: a way of connecting to the internet that allows you to receive information, including pictures, etc., very quickly and that is always active (so that the user does not have to connect each time)

column5: a person whose job is presenting or talking on television or radio programmes
column10: • She is a writer and broadcaster on environmental matters.

column5: generally, without considering details
column10:

  • broadly similar/comparable/equivalent/consistent

column5: violent and cruel

  • a brutal and repressive regime

column5: a US, Australian or New Zealand dollar; a South African rand; an Indian rupee
column10:
• They cost ten bucks.
    • ;
  • We're talking big bucks (= a lot of money) here.

column5: a friend
column10:
• an old college buddy of mine
    • ;
  • Howard and Mick were drinking buddies.
    • ;
  • We were good buddies.
    • ;
  • I’d like you to meet an old college buddy of mine.

column5: a thing or person that reduces a shock or protects somebody/something against difficulties
column10:
• buffer against something Support from family and friends acts as a buffer against stress.

  • buffer between A and B She often had to act as a buffer between father and son.
    • ;
  • The organization acts as a buffer between the management and the union.
    • ;
  • a buffer state (= a small country between two powerful states that helps keep peace between them)
    • ;
  • a buffer zone (= an area of land between two opposing armies or countries)
    • ;
  • Peacekeepers have been sent in to establish a buffer zone between the rival forces.

column5: any small insect
column10: • There's a bug crawling up your arm.

column5: the main part of something; most of something
column10:
• The bulk of the population lives in cities.

  • The great bulk of the work has now been done.

column5: a duty, responsibility, etc. that causes worry, difficulty or hard work
column10:
• to bear/carry/ease/reduce/share the burden
    • ;
  • the burden (of something) The main burden of caring for old people falls on the state.
    • ;
  • burden on somebody the heavy tax burden on working people
    • ;
  • a burden to somebody I don't want to become a burden to my children when I'm old.

column5: the system of official rules and ways of doing things that a government or an organization has, especially when these seem to be too complicated
column10:
• unnecessary/excessive bureaucracy
    • ;
  • We need to reduce paperwork and bureaucracy in the company.

column5: the act or ceremony of burying a dead body
column10:
• a burial place/mound/site
    • ;
  • Her body was sent home for burial.
    • ;

  • baptism, marriage and burial services

column5: to break open or apart, especially because of pressure from inside; to make something break in this way
column10:
• That balloon will burst if you blow it up any more.
    • ;
  • The dam burst under the weight of water.
    • ;
  • Shells were bursting (= exploding) all around us.
    • ;
  • (figurative) He felt he would burst with anger and shame.
    • ;
  • burst apart There was a danger that the engine would burst apart.
    • ;
  • burst something Don't burst that balloon!
    • ;
  • The river burst its banks and flooded nearby towns.
    • ;
  • a burst pipe

column5: a small room on a ship in which you live or sleep

column5: a group of senior members of a government that is responsible for advising and deciding on government policy

  • (British English) the shadow Cabinet (= the most important members of the opposition party)

column5: the act or process of using numbers to find out an amount
column10:
• Cathy did a rough calculation.

column5: a long straight passage dug in the ground and filled with water for boats and ships to travel along; a smaller passage used for carrying water to fields, crops, etc.

  • an irrigation canal

column5: a round stick of wax with a piece of string (called a wick) through the middle that is lit to give light as it burns

• a flickering candle

  • The room was lit by candles.

  • to blow out/snuff out a candle

column5: a strong heavy rough material used for making tents, sails, etc. and by artists for painting on

column5: the ability or qualities necessary to do something

• Age affects the range of a person's capabilities.

column5: an economic system in which a country’s businesses and industry are controlled and run for profit by private owners rather than by the government

column5: based on the principles of capitalism

column5: a chemical element. Carbon is found in all living things, existing in a pure state as diamond and graphite.

column5: the goods carried in a ship, an aircraft or a motor vehicle

• The tanker began to spill its cargo of oil.

column5: a separate section of a train for carrying passengers

  • carve something from/out of something The statue was carved out of a single piece of stone.

  • carve something into/in something The wood had been carved into the shape of a flower.

column5: not formal

column5: being careful about what you say or do, especially to avoid danger or mistakes; not taking any risks

• The government has been cautious in its response to the report.

column11: cautious about doing something He was very cautious about committing himself to anything.

column5: a large hole in the side of a hill or cliff or under the ground

column5: to stop happening or existing; to stop something from happening or existing

  • The kids chased each other around the kitchen table.

• We all cheered as the team came on to the field.

• The condition prevents the blood from circulating freely.

• He left the army and returned to civilian life.

column5: to make something clearer or easier to understand

column5: a person who collects things, either as a hobby or as a job

  • a head-on collision (= between two vehicles that are moving towards each other)

  • a mid-air collision (= between two aircraft while they are flying)

column5: connected with or belonging to a country that controls another country

• in combat He was killed in combat.

  • combat boots

  • aerial combat
    • ;
  • Knightly combats were only a very small part of medieval warfare.

column5: humorous and making you laugh

• a comic monologue/story

column5: to begin to happen; to begin something

column5: a spoken description of an event that is given while it is happening, especially on the radio or television

• a sports commentary
    • ;
  • Our reporters will give a running commentary (= a continuous one) on the election results as they are announced.

  • He kept up a running commentary on everyone who came in or went out.

column5: a person who describes an event while it is happening, especially on television or radio
column10:
• a television/sports commentator
    • ;
  • He's one of the great sports commentators of our time.

column5: trade, especially between countries; the buying and selling of goods and services

column5: a member of a commission (= an official group of people who are responsible for controlling something or finding out about something)

• the Church Commissioners (= the group of people responsible for controlling the financial affairs of the Church of England)

  • European Commissioners

column5: a product or a raw material that can be bought and sold

• rice, flour and other basic commodities
    • ;
  • a drop in commodity prices
    • ;
  • Crude oil is the world's most important commodity.
    • ;
  • basic agricultural commodities

column5: connected with communism

column5: a person or an animal that travels with you or spends a lot of time with you

• travelling companions
    • ;
  • Geoff was my companion on the journey.
    • ;
  • (figurative) Fear was the hostages' constant companion.

column5: similar to somebody/something else and able to be compared
column10:
• A comparable house in the south of the city would cost twice as much.
    • ;
  • comparable to/with somebody/something The situation in the US is not directly comparable to that in the UK.
    • ;

    • ;
  • comparable in something The two machines are comparable in size.

column5: measured or judged by how similar or different it is to something else
column10:
• Then he was living in comparative comfort (= compared with others or with his own life at a previous time).
    • ;
  • The company is a comparative newcomer to the software market (= other companies have been in business much longer).

column5: a strong feeling of sympathy for people or animals who are suffering and a desire to help them
column10:
• to feel/show compassion
    • ;
  • She was known as a hard woman with no compassion, no emotion.
    • ;
  • In an overworked doctor, feelings of compassion are soon lost.

column5: to force somebody to do something; to make something necessary
column10:
• compel somebody to do something The law can compel fathers to make regular payments for their children.

  • I feel compelled to write and tell you how much I enjoyed your book.
    • ;
  • The court has powers to compel witnesses to attend.
    • ;
  • compel something Last year ill health compelled his retirement.

column5: that makes you pay attention to it because it is so interesting and exciting
column10:
• Her latest book makes compelling reading.

  • His eyes were strangely compelling.

column5: to provide something good to balance or reduce the bad effects of damage, loss, etc.

column5: something, especially money, that somebody gives you because they have hurt you, or damaged something that you own; the act of giving this to somebody

• to claim/award/receive compensation
    • ;
  • The employer has a duty to pay full compensation for injuries received at work.
    • ;
  • in compensation to receive £10 000 in compensation
    • ;
  • She received a cash sum by way of compensation.

column5: the ability to do something well
column10:
• to gain a high level of competence in English
    • ;
  • professional/technical competence

column5: having enough skill or knowledge to do something well or to the necessary standard
column10:
• He's very competent in his work.
    • ;
  • competent to do something Make sure the firm is competent to carry out the work.
    • ;
  • I don’t feel competent to comment.
    • ;
  • competent at something She is highly competent at her job.

column5: to produce a book, list, report, etc. by bringing together different items, articles, songs, etc.; to collect information in order to produce a book, list, etc.
column10:
• We are trying to compile a list of suitable people for the job.

  • The album was compiled from live recordings from last year's tour.
    • ;
  • The figures were compiled from a survey of 2  000 schoolchildren.

column5: to add to something in a way that improves it or makes it more attractive

• The excellent menu is complemented by a good wine list.

column5: the act or process of finishing something; the state of being finished and complete

    • ;
  • the date of completion/the completion date

column5: the state of being formed of many parts; the state of being difficult to understand

• the increasing complexity of modern telecommunication systems

column5: the practice of obeying rules or requests made by people in authority

  • (business) The compliance officer is responsible for enforcing policies and procedures.

column5: a thing that makes a situation more complicated or difficult
column10: • The bad weather added a further complication to our journey.

column5: to obey a rule, an order, etc.; to meet particular standards

• They refused to comply with the UN resolution.
    • ;
  • All furniture must comply with the fire safety regulations.
    • ;

    • ;
  • What sanctions can they take against us if we fail to comply?

column5: to write music
column10:
• Mozart composed his last opera shortly before he died.

  • music specially composed for the occasion

column5: a person who writes music, especially classical music

column5: the different parts that something is made of; the way in which the different parts are organized

• the chemical composition of the soil

  • the composition of the board of directors
    • ;
  • the size and composition of an average class

column5: a thing consisting of two or more separate things combined together

• compounds derived from rainforest plants

  • The air smelled like a compound of diesel and petrol fumes.

column5: including all, or almost all, the items, details, facts, information, etc., that may be involved

• a comprehensive list of addresses

  • a comprehensive study

column5: to have somebody/something as parts or members

• comprise something The collection comprises 327 paintings.

  • a DVD box set comprising seasons 4 and 5

column5: an agreement made between two people or groups in which each side gives up some of the things they want so that both sides are happy at the end

• After lengthy talks the two sides finally reached a compromise.

column5: to give up some of your demands in order to reach an agreement after disagreeing with somebody
column10:
• Neither side is prepared to compromise.

  • compromise (with somebody) (on something) After much argument, the judges finally compromised on (= agreed to give the prize to) the 18-year old pianist.

  • They were unwilling to compromise with the terrorists.

column5: that must be done because of a law or a rule

• English is a compulsory subject at this level.

    • ;

column5: to calculate something

• The losses were computed at £5 million.

column5: to admit that something is true, logical, etc. after first denying it or resisting it

• + speech ‘Not bad,’ she conceded grudgingly.

  • concede (that)… He was forced to concede (that) there might be difficulties.
    • ;

    • ;
  • concede something to somebody He reluctantly conceded the point to me.
    • ;
  • concede somebody something He reluctantly conceded me the point.

  • it is conceded that… It must be conceded that different judges have different approaches to these cases.

column5: to form an idea, a plan, etc. in your mind

• He conceived the idea of transforming the old power station into an arts centre.

  • The dam project was originally conceived in 1977.

column5: an understanding or a belief of what something/somebody is or what something/somebody should be

• conception of something Marx’s conception of social justice

  • He has no conception of how difficult life is if you're unemployed.

column5: something that you allow or do, or allow somebody to have, in order to end an argument or to make a situation less difficult
column10:
• The firm will be forced to make concessions if it wants to avoid a strike.

  • to win a concession from somebody
    • ;
  • a major/an important concession
    • ;
  • She made no concession to his age; she expected him to work as hard as she did.

column5: made of concrete

• a slab of concrete

column5: to say very strongly that you think something is bad, usually for moral reasons

• condemn somebody/something The government issued a statement condemning the killings.

column5: to discuss something with somebody, in order to exchange opinions or get advice

column5: to admit, especially formally or to the police, that you have done something wrong or illegal

• After hours of questioning, the suspect confessed.

  • confess to (doing) something She confessed to the murder.

    • ;
  • confess to somebody (that)… She confessed to me that she had known his true identity for some time.
    • ;
  • confess your crime, error, etc. We persuaded her to confess her crime.

• After hours of questioning by police, she made a full confession.

  • His confession was extracted under torture.

• be confined to (doing) something The work will not be confined to the Glasgow area.

column5: a statement, letter, etc. that shows that something is true, correct or definite

• a congressional committee/bill

  • the midterm Congressional elections

• The Normans conquered England in 1066.

  • In 330 BC Persia was conquered by Alexander the Great.

column5: the part of your mind that tells you whether your actions are right or wrong

• to have a clear/guilty conscience (= to feel that you have done right/wrong)

column5: the state of being able to use your senses and mental powers to understand what is happening

column5: an opinion that all members of a group agree with

  • consensus that… There seems to be a consensus that the plan should be rejected.
    • ;

column5: permission to do something, especially given by somebody in authority

• The written consent of a parent is required.

  • consent to something Children under 16 cannot give consent to medical treatment.

column5: to agree to something or give your permission for something
column10:
• When she told them what she intended, they readily consented.
    • ;
  • consent to something He reluctantly consented to the proposal.
    • ;
  • consent to do something She finally consented to answer our questions.

column5: as a result; therefore

• This poses a threat to agriculture and the food chain, and consequently to human health.

  • She failed her exams and was consequently unable to start her studies at college.

• to be interested in wildlife conservation

column5: to protect something and prevent it from being changed or destroyed

column5: great in amount, size, importance, etc.

column5: always the same

• conspiracy (to do something) a conspiracy to overthrow the government

  • They were charged with conspiracy to murder.

  • conspiracy against somebody/something conspiracies against the president

  • a conspiracy of silence (= an agreement not to talk publicly about something that should be made public)

column5: a district that elects its own representative to parliament

• Unemployment is high in her constituency.

column5: to be considered to be something

column5: the system of laws and basic principles that a state, a country or an organization is governed by

column5: a thing that limits something, or limits your freedom to do something

• constraints of time/money/space

column5: to go to somebody for information or advice
column10:
• consult somebody If the pain continues, consult your doctor.

  • consult somebody about something Have you consulted your lawyer about this?

  • a consulting engineer (= one who has expert knowledge and gives advice)

  • (North American English) consult with somebody (about/on something) Consult with your physician about possible treatments.

column5: a person who knows a lot about a particular subject and is employed to give advice about it to other people
column10:
• a technology/design consultant
    • ;
  • She is clearly being coached by image consultants.
    • ;
  • consultant on something the president’s consultant on economic affairs
    • ;
  • consultant to somebody/something He was happy to act as a consultant to the company.

column5: the act of discussing something with somebody or with a group of people before making a decision about it
column10:
• a consultation document/paper/period/process

  • consultation with somebody/something The decision was taken after close consultation with local residents.
    • ;
  • in consultation with somebody/something acting in consultation with all the departments involved

column5: the act of using energy, food or materials; the amount used

• the production of fuel for domestic consumption (= to be used in the country where it is produced)

  • Gas and oil consumption always increases in cold weather.

  • The meat was declared unfit for human consumption.
    • ;
  • He was advised to reduce his alcohol consumption.
    • ;
  • consumption of something Doctors say that children need to increase their consumption of fruit and vegetables.
    • ;
  • (figurative) Her speech to party members was not intended for public consumption (= to be heard by the public).

column5: to think about whether you should do something, or how you should do something

• contemplate something You're too young to be contemplating retirement.
    • ;
  • contemplate doing something I have never contemplated living abroad.
    • ;
  • contemplate how/what, etc… He continued while she contemplated how to answer.

column5: the feeling that somebody/something is without value and deserves no respect at all
column10:
• with contempt She looked at him with contempt.

  • I shall treat that suggestion with the contempt it deserves.

  • beneath contempt His treatment of his children is beneath contempt (= so bad that it is not even worth feeling contempt for).
    • ;
  • in contempt Politicians seem to be generally held in contempt by ordinary people.
    • ;
  • contempt for somebody/something They had shown a contempt for the values she thought important.

column5: to say that something is true, especially in an argument
column10: • I would contend that the minister's thinking is flawed on this point.

column5: a person or team with a chance of winning a competition
column10:
• contender (for something) a contender for a gold medal in the Olympics
    • ;
  • a leading/serious/strong contender for the party leadership
    • ;
  • contender to do something Germany last night emerged as a contender to stage next year's event.

column5: happy and satisfied with what you have
column10:
• He seemed more content, less bitter.
    • ;
  • content with something Not content with stealing my boyfriend (= not thinking that this was enough), she has turned all my friends against me.

  • He had to be content with third place.

column5: anger between people who disagree
column10:
• One area of contention is the availability of nursery care.

  • Privatization of the health service remains a point of contention.
    • ;
  • There is no contention between the two groups.

column5: in a way that is repeated many times so that it is annoying
column10: • They argue continually about money.

column5: a person or company that has a contract to do work or provide goods or services for another company
column10:
• a building/roofing/electrical contractor
    • ;
  • a defence/security/military/civilian contractor
    • ;
  • a private/an independent contractor
    • ;
  • to employ an outside contractor

column5: a lack of agreement between facts, opinions, actions, etc.
column10:
• contradiction (between A and B) There is a contradiction between the two sets of figures.
    • ;
  • How can we resolve this apparent contradiction?
    • ;
  • in contradiction to something His public speeches are in direct contradiction to his personal lifestyle.

column5: different from something; against something
column10:
• Contrary to popular belief, many cats dislike milk.
    • ;
  • The government has decided that the publication of the report would be ‘contrary to the public interest’.
    • ;
  • Contrary to expectations and the weather forecast, we had a fine day for the experiment.

column5: the opposite fact, event or situation
column10: • In the end the contrary was proved true: he was innocent and she was guilty.

column5: a person who writes articles for a magazine, book or website, or who talks on a radio or television programme or at a meeting
column10:
• a regular contributor to this magazine
    • ;
  • I am a contributor to several blogs.

column5: causing a lot of angry public discussion and disagreement
column10:
• a highly controversial topic
    • ;
  • one of the most controversial of London’s new office blocks
    • ;
  • A controversial plan to build a new road has met with protests.
    • ;
  • Winston Churchill and Richard Nixon were both controversial figures.

column5: public discussion and argument about something that many people strongly disagree about, think is bad, or are shocked by
column10:
• to arouse/cause controversy
    • ;
  • a bitter controversy over/about the site of the new airport
    • ;
  • The controversy surrounding his latest movie continues.
    • ;
  • The President resigned amid considerable controversy.

column5: the quality of being useful, easy or suitable for somebody

• We have provided seats for the convenience of our customers.
    • ;
  • For (the sake of) convenience, the two groups have been treated as one in this report.

  • The position of the house combines quietness and convenience.
    • ;
  • In this resort you can enjoy all the comfort and convenience of modern tourism.

column5: the way in which something is done that most people in a society expect and consider to be polite or the right way to do it

• the rigid social conventions of Victorian Britain
    • ;
  • She is a young woman who enjoys flouting conventions.
    • ;
  • by convention By convention the deputy leader was always a woman.
    • ;
  • Convention demands that a club member should resign in such a situation.

column5: tending to follow what is done or considered acceptable by society in general; normal and ordinary, and perhaps not very interesting
column10:
• conventional behaviour/morality
    • ;
  • She's very conventional in her views.

column5: the act or process of changing something from one form, use or system to another
column10:
• Their main business is the conversion of farm buildings into family homes.
    • ;
  • Conversion to gas central heating will save you a lot of money.
    • ;
  • No conversion from analogue to digital data is needed.
    • ;
  • a metric conversion table (= showing how to change metric amounts into or out of another system)
    • ;
  • a firm which specializes in house conversions (= turning large houses into several smaller flats)

column5: to make ideas, feelings, etc. known to somebody
column10:
• convey something Colours like red convey a sense of energy and strength.
    • ;
  • convey something to somebody (formal) Please convey my apologies to your wife.
    • ;
  • convey how, what, etc… He tried desperately to convey how urgent the situation was.
    • ;
  • convey that… She did not wish to convey that they were all at fault.

column5: to decide and state officially in court that somebody is guilty of a crime
column10:
• be convicted (of something) He was convicted of fraud.
    • ;
  • a convicted murderer
    • ;
  • convict somebody (of something) There wasn’t enough evidence to convict her.

column5: the act of finding somebody guilty of a crime in court; the fact of having been found guilty
column10:
• He plans to appeal against his conviction.
    • ;
  • conviction for something She has six previous convictions for theft.
    • ;
  • on conviction an offence that carries, on conviction, a sentence of not more than five years’ imprisonment

column5: that makes somebody believe that something is true
column10:
• a convincing argument/explanation/case
    • ;
  • She sounded very convincing to me (= I believed what she said).
    • ;
  • a convincing victory/win (= an easy one)

column5: to work together with somebody else in order to achieve something
column10:
• The two groups agreed to cooperate with each other.
    • ;
  • They had cooperated closely in the planning of the project.

column5: involving doing something together or working together with others towards a shared aim
column10:
• Cooperative activity is essential to effective community work.
    • ;
  • The documentary was a cooperative effort by film-makers from five countries.
    • ;
  • This is a cooperative venture with the University of Copenhagen.

column5: to organize the different parts of an activity and the people involved in it so that it works well
column10:
• coordinate something They appointed a new manager to coordinate the work of the team.
    • ;
  • We need to develop a coordinated approach to the problem.
    • ;
  • a carefully coordinated policy
    • ;
  • coordinate something with something We try to coordinate our activities with those of other groups.

column5: the act of making parts of something, groups of people, etc. work together in an efficient and organized way
column10:
• The aim was to improve the coordination of services.
    • ;
  • coordination between A and B a need for greater coordination between departments
    • ;
  • coordination in something a lack of coordination in conservation policy
    • ;
  • in coordination with somebody/something a pamphlet produced by the government in coordination with (= working together with) the Sports Council
    • ;
  • advice on colour coordination (= choosing colours that look nice together, for example in clothes or furniture)

column5: a person who organizes the different parts of an activity and the people involved in it so that it works well
column10: • The campaign needs an effective coordinator.

column5: a police officer
column10:
• Somebody call the cops!
    • ;
  • children playing cops and robbers
    • ;
  • a TV cop show

column5: to deal successfully with something difficult
column10:
• I got to the stage where I wasn't coping any more.
    • ;
  • cope with something He wasn't able to cope with the stresses and strains of the job.
    • ;
  • Desert plants are adapted to cope with extreme heat.

column5: a chemical element. Copper is a soft red-brown metal used for making electric wires, pipes and coins.
column10:
• a copper mine
    • ;
  • copper pipes
    • ;
  • copper-coloured hair

column5: if a person or an organization holds the copyright on a piece of writing, music, etc., they are the only people who have the legal right to publish, broadcast, perform it, etc., and other people must ask their permission to use it or any part of it
column10:
• Copyright expires seventy years after the death of the author.
    • ;
  • They were sued for breach/infringement of copyright.
    • ;
  • copyright in/on something Who owns the copyright on this song?
    • ;
  • out of copyright His work is now out of copyright.
    • ;
  • in copyright The songs remain in copyright.

column5: a large business company
column10:
• multinational corporations
    • ;
  • the Chrysler corporation

column5: a change that makes something more accurate than it was before
column10:
• I've made a few small corrections to your report.
    • ;
  • The paper had to publish a correction to the story.

column5: if two or more facts, figures, etc. correlate or if a fact, figure, etc. correlates with another, the facts are closely connected and affect or depend on each other
column10:
• The figures do not seem to correlate.
    • ;
  • correlate with something A high-fat diet correlates with a greater risk of heart disease.
    • ;
  • The average speed of the vehicles correlates closely with the severity of the accident caused.

column5: a connection between two things in which one thing changes as the other does
column10:
• correlation between A and B There is a direct correlation between exposure to sun and skin cancer.
    • ;
  • correlation of A with B the correlation of social power with wealth

column5: to be the same as or match something
column10:
• Your account and hers do not correspond.
    • ;
  • correspond with something Your account of events does not correspond with hers.
    • ;
  • correspond to something The written record of the conversation doesn't correspond to (= is different from) what was actually said.

column5: the letters, emails, etc. a person sends and receives
column10:
• personal/private correspondence
    • ;
  • The editor welcomes correspondence from readers on any subject.
    • ;
  • the correspondence column/page (= in a newspaper)
    • ;
  • correspondence with somebody Jane Austen's correspondence with her sister

column5: a person who reports news from a particular country or on a particular subject for a newspaper or a television or radio station
column10:
• She's the BBC's political correspondent.
    • ;
  • a foreign/war/sports correspondent
    • ;
  • our Delhi correspondent

column5: matching or connected with something that you have just mentioned
column10:
• A change in the money supply brings a corresponding change in expenditure.
    • ;
  • Profits have risen by 15 per cent compared with the corresponding period last year.
    • ;
  • The Redskins lost to the Cowboys in the corresponding game last year.
    • ;
  • Fewer houses are available, but there is no corresponding decrease in demand.
    • ;
  • corresponding to something Give each picture a number corresponding to its position on the page.

column5: a long narrow passage in a building, with doors that open into rooms on either side
column10: • His room is along the corridor.

column5: willing to use their power to do dishonest or illegal things in return for money or to get an advantage
column10:
• It was seen as the only way to overthrow a corrupt regime.
    • ;
  • They promised to seek out the corrupt officials who had accepted the bribes.
    • ;
  • one of the most notoriously corrupt city councils

column5: dishonest or illegal behaviour, especially of people in authority
column10:
• allegations of bribery and corruption
    • ;
  • The new district attorney has promised to fight police corruption.

column5: costing a lot of money, especially more than you want to pay
column10: • Buying new furniture may prove too costly.

column5: a member of a city or county council
column10:
• Councillor Ann Jones
    • ;
  • Talk to your local councillor about the problem.

column5: professional advice about a problem
column10:
• The couple decided to go for relationship counselling.
    • ;
  • Some groups offer bereavement counselling.
    • ;
  • a student counselling service

column5: a person who has been trained to advise people with problems, especially personal problems
column10: • I went to see a debt counsellor and she agreed to come to the bank with me.

column5: a long flat surface over which goods are sold or business is done in a shop, bank, etc.
column10: • behind the counter I asked the woman behind the counter if they had any postcards.

column5: to reply to somebody by trying to prove that what they said is not true
column10:
• counter somebody/something Such arguments are not easily countered.
    • ;
  • counter that… I tried to argue but he countered that the plans were not yet finished.
    • ;
  • counter (somebody) + speech ‘But I was standing right here!’ he countered.
    • ;
  • counter (somebody/something) with something Butler has countered with a lawsuit against the firm.

column5: a person or thing that has the same position or function as somebody/something else in a different place or situation
column10:
• The Foreign Minister held talks with his Chinese counterpart.
    • ;
  • The women's shoe, like its male counterpart, is specifically designed for the serious tennis player.

column5: very many; too many to be counted or mentioned
column10:
• I've warned her countless times.
    • ;
  • The new treatment could save Emma's life and the lives of countless others.

column5: a sudden change of government that is illegal and often violent
column10:
• He seized power in a military coup in 2008.
    • ;
  • to stage/mount a coup
    • ;
  • He was sentenced to death for his part in the attempted coup.
    • ;
  • a failed/an abortive coup
    • ;
  • She lost her position in a boardroom coup (= a sudden change of power among senior managers in a company).

column5: polite behaviour that shows respect for other people
column10:
• I was treated with the utmost courtesy by the staff.
    • ;
  • We asked them, as a matter of courtesy, if we could photograph their house.
    • ;
  • It's only common courtesy to tell the neighbours that we'll be having a party (= the sort of behaviour that people would expect).

column5: the reporting of news and sport in the media
column10:
• media/newspaper/press coverage
    • ;
  • tonight’s live coverage of the hockey game
    • ;
  • There was blanket coverage (= reports everywhere) of the royal divorce.

column5: a line on the surface of something where it has broken but not split into separate parts
column10:
• This cup has a crack in it.
    • ;
  • Cracks began to appear in the walls.
    • ;
  • (figurative) The cracks (= faults) in the government's economic policy are already beginning to show.

column5: to break without dividing into separate parts; to break something in this way
column10:
• The ice cracked as I stepped onto it.
    • ;
  • crack something He has cracked a bone in his arm.

column5: an activity involving a special skill at making things with your hands
column10:
• traditional crafts like basket-weaving
    • ;
  • a craft fair/workshop

column5: to make something using special skills, especially with your hands
column10:
• be crafted (from something) All the furniture is crafted from natural materials.
    • ;
  • a carefully crafted speech

column5: to move forward on your hands and knees or with your body close to the ground
column10:
• Our baby is just starting to crawl.
    • ;
  • A man was crawling away from the burning wreckage.
    • ;
  • She crawled under the fence.

column5: the use of skill and imagination to produce something new or to produce art
column10: • Creativity and originality are more important than technical skill.

column5: a person who has made or invented a particular thing
column10: • Walt Disney, the creator of Mickey Mouse

column5: the quality that somebody/something has that makes people believe or trust them
column10:
• to gain/lack/lose credibility
    • ;
  • The prosecution did its best to undermine the credibility of the witness.
    • ;
  • After the recent scandal, the government has lost all credibility.
    • ;
  • Newspapers were talking of a credibility gap between what he said and what he did.

column5: that can be believed or trusted
column10:
• a credible explanation/witness
    • ;
  • It is just not credible that she would cheat.

column5: to move slowly, quietly and carefully, because you do not want to be seen or heard
column10:
• I crept up the stairs, trying not to wake my parents.
    • ;
  • I heard someone creeping around the house.

column5: in a way that says what you think is bad about somebody/something
column10: • She spoke critically of her father.

column5: a piece of written criticism of a set of ideas, a work of art, etc.
column10: • She wrote a feminist critique of Freud's theories.

column5: an object in the shape of a circle, usually made of gold and precious stones, that a king or queen wears on his or her head on official occasions
column10:
• The crown was placed upon the new monarch's head.
    • ;
  • the emperor's jewel-encrusted crown

column5: in its natural state, before it has been processed or refined
column10: • crude oil/metal

column5: a journey by sea, visiting different places, especially as a holiday
column10:
• I'd love to go on a round-the-world cruise.
    • ;
  • a luxury cruise ship

column5: to travel in a ship or boat visiting different places, especially as a holiday
column10:
• (+ adv./prep.) They cruised down the Nile.
    • ;
  • cruise something We spent two weeks cruising the Bahamas.

column5: to press something so hard that it is damaged or injured, or loses its shape
column10:
• The car was completely crushed under the truck.
    • ;
  • Several people were crushed to death in the accident.

column5: a small piece of a substance with many even sides, that is formed naturally when the substance becomes solid
column10: • ice/salt crystals

column5: an action or event that is a signal for somebody to do something

• cue (for something) Jon's arrival was a cue for more champagne.

  • cue to do something I think that's my cue to explain why I'm here.

column5: very popular with a particular group of people

• a cult movie/book

  • The singer has become a cult figure in America.

  • The TV series has a cult following among young people.

column5: a way of life, an attitude, an idea, etc. that has become very popular

• the cult of physical fitness
    • ;
  • the cult of youth

column5: to prepare and use land for growing plants or crops
column10:
• The land around here has never been cultivated.
    • ;
  • The land here has been intensively cultivated for generations.

column5: a strong desire to know about something
column10:
• Children show curiosity about everything.
    • ;
  • I felt a certain curiosity to see what would happen next.
    • ;
  • The letter wasn't addressed to me but I opened it out of curiosity.
    • ;
  • His answer did not satisfy my curiosity at all.
    • ;
  • Sophie's curiosity was aroused by the mysterious phone call.

  • intellectual curiosity
    • ;
  • ‘Why do you ask?’ ‘Oh, just idle curiosity’ (= no particular reason).

column5: having a strong desire to know about something
column10:
• He is such a curious boy, always asking questions.
    • ;
  • curious about something They were very curious about the people who lived upstairs.
    • ;
  • curious as to something Everyone was curious as to why Mark was leaving.
    • ;
  • curious to do something I was curious to find out what she had said.

column5: the subjects that are included in a course of study or taught in a school, college, etc.
column10:
• The school curriculum should be as broad as possible.

  • on the curriculum (British English) Spanish is on the curriculum.

  • in the curriculum (North American English) Spanish is in the curriculum.

column5: the legal right or duty to take care of or keep somebody/something; the act of taking care of something/somebody

• Who will have custody of the children?

  • The parents were given joint custody of the two children.

  • The divorce court awarded custody to the child's mother.

  • The parents were locked in a bitter battle for custody.

  • The bank provides safe custody for valuables.

column5: pretty and attractive
column10:
• a cute little baby
    • ;
  • She's so cute!

  • (British English) an unbearably cute picture of two kittens (= it seems sentimental)

column5: an article or a story that you cut from a newspaper or magazine and keep

column5: believing that people only do things to help themselves rather than for good or honest reasons

• a cynical view/smile
    • ;

column5: made from milk

column5: milk, cheese and other milk products

• the Narmada dam in India

    • ;
  • The dam burst and the valley was flooded.

• damaging consequences/effects

  • damaging to somebody/something Lead is potentially damaging to children's health.

column5: the state of being dark, without any light

  • There is an extra hour of darkness on winter mornings.

  • Her face was in darkness.

• The database is updated monthly.

  • The new database contains 200 000 images.

  • summer’s early dawns

  • He works from dawn till dusk (= from morning till night).

column5: a point in time by which something must be done

  • The terrorists have chosen to play a deadly game with the civilian population.

column5: a person whose business is buying and selling a particular product

• an art/antique dealer

column5: very important for the final result of a particular situation

  • Climate was a decisive factor in establishing where the tournament should be held.

• on deck I was the only person on deck at that time of night.

  • When we heard the alarm, we went up on deck.

column5: an official or formal statement, especially about the plans of a government or an organization; the act of making such a statement

    • ;
  • the declaration of war

  • the Declaration of Independence (= of the United States)
    • ;
  • The declaration asked governments to consider introducing new environmental taxes.

column5: working hard at something because it is very important to you

• a dedicated teacher
    • ;
  • dedicated to something She is dedicated to her job.

column5: the hard work and effort that somebody puts into an activity or a purpose because they think it is important
column10:
• hard work and dedication
    • ;
  • dedication to somebody/something I really admire Gina for her dedication to her family.

column5: a thing that somebody does that is usually very good or very bad

• It's a stirring tale of heroic deeds.
    • ;
  • a brave/charitable deed
    • ;
  • She tried to do a good deed every day.
    • ;
  • They will be punished for their evil deeds.

column5: to have a particular opinion about somebody/something

• deem somebody/something + noun The evening was deemed a great success.

  • deem somebody/something + adj. She deemed it prudent not to say anything.

  • I deem it an honour to be invited.

column5: a fault in something or in the way it has been made that means that it is not perfect

• As a defensive measure he built a series of coastal forts and watchtowers.

column5: a public meeting or a march (= an organized walk by many people) at which people show that they are protesting against or supporting somebody/something

  • to hold/stage a demonstration

  • mass demonstrations in support of the exiled leader

    • ;

column5: a statement that something is not true or does not exist; the action of denying something

column10:
• 2 000 troops were deployed in the area.
    • ;
  • At least 5 000 missiles were deployed along the border.
    • ;
  • Tanks were deployed effectively during the long campaign.

column5: the act of moving soldiers or weapons into a position where they are ready for military action
column10:
• the deployment of peacekeeping forces
    • ;
  • troop deployments

column5: a sum of money that is given as the first part of a larger payment
column10:
• They normally ask you to pay $100 (as a) deposit.
    • ;
  • All deposits are non-refundable.
    • ;
  • deposit on something (British English) We've put down a 5% deposit on the house.

column5: to put money into a bank account
column10:
• Millions were deposited in Swiss bank accounts.
    • ;
  • You can withdraw and deposit money in any of our branches.

column5: a medical condition in which a person feels very sad and anxious and often has physical symptoms such as being unable to sleep, etc.
column10:
• She was diagnosed as having clinical depression.
    • ;
  • She suffered from severe depression after losing her job.

column5: a person who is the next most important person below a business manager, a head of a school, a political leader, etc. and who does that person’s job when they are away
column10:
• I'm acting as deputy till the manager returns.
    • ;
  • She was appointed deputy head of the school.

column5: to come or go down from a higher to a lower level
column10:
• The plane began to descend.
    • ;
  • The results, ranked in descending order (= from the highest to the lowest) are as follows…
    • ;
  • descend something She descended the stairs slowly.

column5: an action of coming or going down
column10:
• The plane began its descent to Heathrow.
    • ;
  • (figurative) the country’s swift descent into anarchy

column5: to say officially that somebody/something has a particular character or name; to describe somebody/something in a particular way
column10:
• be designated (as) something This area has been designated (as) a National Park.
    • ;
  • The school has been designated a specialist science academy.
    • ;
  • be designated (as being/having something) Several pupils were designated as having moderate or severe learning difficulties.
    • ;
  • a designated nature reserve
    • ;
  • designated seats for the elderly

column5: that you would like to have or do; worth having or doing
column10:
• She chatted for a few minutes about the qualities she considered desirable in a secretary.
    • ;
  • Such measures are desirable, if not essential.
    • ;
  • The house has many desirable features.
    • ;
  • Experience of computers is highly desirable.
    • ;
  • It is desirable that… (British English) It is desirable that interest rates should be reduced.
    • ;
  • (especially North American English) It is desirable that interest rates be reduced.
    • ;
  • It is desirable (for somebody) (to do something) It is no longer desirable for such young children to take formal written tests.

column5: a screen on a computer that shows the icons of programs and files that can be used
column10: • desktop icons

column5: in a way that shows you have little hope and are ready to do anything without worrying about danger to yourself or others
column10: • She looked desperately around for a weapon.

column5: the act of destroying something; the process of being destroyed
column10:
• the destruction of the rainforests
    • ;
  • a tidal wave bringing death and destruction in its wake
    • ;
  • The central argument is that capitalism sows the seeds of its own destruction (= creates the forces that destroy it).

column5: causing destruction or damage
column10:
• The war demonstrated the destructive power of modern weapons.
    • ;
  • the destructive effects of anxiety
    • ;
  • Opencast coal mining is among the most environmentally destructive activities carried out in Wales.

column5: to keep somebody in an official place, such as a police station, a prison or a hospital, and prevent them from leaving
column10: • One man has been detained for questioning.

column5: the process of discovering or noticing something, especially something that is not easy to see, hear, etc.; the fact of being discovered or noticed
column10:
• crime prevention and detection
    • ;
  • Last year the detection rate for car theft was just 13 per cent.
    • ;
  • Many problems, however, escape detection.
    • ;
  • Early detection of cancers is vitally important.

column5: the state of being kept in a place, especially a prison, and prevented from leaving
column10:
• They were sentenced to 12 months' detention in a young offender institution.
    • ;
  • police powers of arrest and detention
    • ;
  • allegations of torture and detention without trial
    • ;
  • a detention camp

column5: to become worse
column10:
• Her health deteriorated rapidly, and she died shortly afterwards.
    • ;
  • They had to cope with deteriorating weather conditions.
    • ;
  • deteriorate into something The discussion quickly deteriorated into an angry argument.

column5: the quality that makes you continue trying to do something even when this is difficult
column10:
• fierce/grim/dogged determination
    • ;
  • He fought the illness with courage and determination.
    • ;
  • They had survived by sheer determination.
    • ;
  • determination to do something I admire her determination to get it right.

column5: to completely destroy a place or an area
column10: • The bomb devastated much of the old part of the city.

column5: the most powerful evil being
column10:
• belief in the Devil
    • ;
  • His strong left-wing views make him the devil incarnate to more extreme Conservatives.

column5: to invent something new or a new way of doing something
column10: • A new system has been devised to control traffic in the city.

column5: to say exactly what an illness or the cause of a problem is
column10:
• diagnose something The test is used to diagnose a variety of diseases.
    • ;
  • diagnose something as something The illness was diagnosed as cancer.
    • ;
  • diagnose somebody with something He has recently been diagnosed with angina.
    • ;
  • diagnose somebody/something (as) something I quickly diagnosed the problem as a faulty battery.
    • ;
  • He was diagnosed (as) a diabetic when he was 64.
    • ;
  • diagnose somebody + adj./noun He was diagnosed (a) diabetic.

column5: the act of discovering or identifying the exact cause of an illness or a problem
column10:
• a diagnosis of lung cancer
    • ;
  • They are waiting for the doctor's diagnosis.
    • ;
  • An accurate diagnosis was made after a series of tests.
    • ;
  • They are using new methods of diagnosis.

column5: to tell somebody what to do, especially in an annoying way
column10:
• dictate something (to somebody) They are in no position to dictate terms (= tell other people what to do).
    • ;
  • dictate how, what, etc…/that… What right do they have to dictate how we live our lives?

column5: a political leader who has complete power over a country, especially one who has gained it using military force
column10: • The country suffered at the hands of a series of military dictators.

column5: to be different from somebody/something
column10:
• They hold differing views.
    • ;
  • A differs from B French differs from English in this respect.
    • ;
  • A and B differ (from each other) French and English differ in this respect.
    • ;
  • differ between A and B Ideas on childcare may differ considerably between the parents.

column5: to recognize or show that two things are not the same
column10:
• differentiate (between) A and B It's difficult to differentiate between the two varieties.
    • ;
  • differentiate A (from B) I can't differentiate one variety from another.

column5: a calm and serious manner that deserves respect
column10:
• She accepted the criticism with quiet dignity.
    • ;
  • He brings a quiet dignity to the role.
    • ;
  • His aristocratic voice gives him an air of dignity and power.

column5: a situation that makes problems, often one in which you have to make a very difficult choice between things of equal importance
column10:
• I could see no way of resolving this moral dilemma.
    • ;
  • The digital era brings new ethical dilemmas for journalists.
    • ;
  • in a dilemma They were caught in a real dilemma.
    • ;
  • dilemma about/over something She faced a dilemma about whether to accept the offer or not.
    • ;
  • dilemma between A and B the perennial dilemma between work and family commitments

column5: a measurement in space, for example how high, wide or long something is
column10:
• We measured the dimensions of the kitchen.
    • ;
  • computer design tools that work in three dimensions

column5: to become smaller, weaker, etc.; to make something become smaller, weaker, etc.
column10:
• The world's resources are rapidly diminishing.
    • ;
  • His influence has diminished with time.
    • ;
  • diminish something The new law is expected to diminish the government's chances.

column5: to put something quickly into a liquid and take it out again
column10:
• dip something (into something) He dipped the brush into the paint.
    • ;
  • dip something (in) Dip your hand in to see how hot the water is.
    • ;
  • The fruit had been dipped in chocolate.

column5: a person whose job is to represent his or her country in a foreign country, for example, in an embassy

• Washington's top diplomat in Havana
    • ;
  • a Western diplomat in Islamabad

• a diplomatic crisis

    • ;
  • to break off/establish/restore diplomatic relations with a country

column5: a book or electronic resource containing lists of information, usually in alphabetical order, for example people’s phone numbers or the names and addresses of businesses in a particular area
column10:
• a telephone/trade directory
    • ;
  • a directory of European Trade Associations

column5: a physical or mental condition that means you cannot use a part of your body completely or easily, or that you cannot learn easily
column10:
• a physical/mental disability

  • with a disability people with severe learning disabilities

column5: unable to use a part of your body completely or easily because of a physical condition, an illness, an injury, etc.; unable to learn easily
column10:
• physically/mentally disabled
    • ;
  • a new home for severely disabled people
    • ;
  • He was born disabled.
    • ;
  • The museum has special facilities for disabled people.
    • ;
  • Does the theatre have disabled access?

column5: a situation where people have different opinions about something and often argue
column10:
• disagreement (about/on/over/as to something) Disagreement arose about exactly how to plan the show.
    • ;
  • disagreement on the method to be used
    • ;
  • There's no room for disagreement on this point.
    • ;
  • There is considerable disagreement over the safety of the treatment.
    • ;
  • We are in total disagreement as to how to proceed.
    • ;
  • disagreement (between A and B) It was a source of disagreement between the two states.

  • disagreement (among…) There is disagreement among archaeologists as to the age of the sculpture.
    • ;
  • disagreement (with somebody) They have had several disagreements with their neighbours.
    • ;
  • in disagreement He shook his head in disagreement.

column5: to make somebody feel sad because something that they hope for or expect to happen does not happen or is not as good as they hoped
column10:
• disappoint (somebody) Her decision to cancel the concert is bound to disappoint her fans.
    • ;
  • I hate to disappoint you, but I'm just not interested.
    • ;
  • The movie had disappointed her (= it wasn't as good as she had expected).
    • ;
  • I hate to disappoint the children when they've been looking forward to it so much.
    • ;
  • His latest novel does not disappoint.
    • ;
  • it disappoints somebody that… It disappointed me that nobody bothered to say thank you.

column5: the feeling of being sad because something has not happened or been as good, successful, etc. as you expected or hoped
column10:
• Book early for the show to avoid disappointment.
    • ;
  • To our great disappointment, it rained every day of the trip.
    • ;
  • He found it difficult to hide his disappointment when she didn't arrive.

column5: very bad, harmful or unsuccessful
column10:
• a disastrous harvest/fire/result
    • ;
  • Lowering interest rates could have disastrous consequences for the economy.
    • ;
  • It was a disastrous start to the season for the team.

column5: to get rid of something that you no longer want or need

• discard somebody/something The room was littered with discarded newspapers.

  • He had discarded his jacket because of the heat.
    • ;
  • (figurative) She could now discard all thought of promotion.
    • ;
  • discard somebody/something as something 10 per cent of the data was discarded as unreliable.

column5: to give somebody official permission to leave the police or the armed forces; to make somebody leave the police or the armed forces
column10:
• be discharged from something He was discharged from the army following his injury.
    • ;
  • She was discharged from the police force for bad conduct.
    • ;
  • He was found guilty and dishonourably discharged from the army.

column5: to give somebody information about something, especially something that was previously secret
column10:
• disclose something (to somebody) The spokesman refused to disclose details of the takeover to the press.

  • disclose that… The report discloses that human error was to blame for the accident.
    • ;
  • it is disclosed that… It was disclosed that two women were being interviewed by the police.
    • ;
  • disclose what, whether, etc… I cannot disclose what we discussed.

column5: the act of making something known or public that was previously secret or private
column10:
• the newspaper’s disclosure of defence secrets
    • ;
  • The bank will need full disclosure of your financial situation and assets.
    • ;
  • The court ruled to prevent public disclosure of the contents of the documents.

column5: to try to prevent something or to prevent somebody from doing something, especially by making it difficult to do or by showing that you do not approve of it

• discourage (doing) something a campaign to discourage smoking among teenagers

  • discourage somebody I leave a light on when I'm out to discourage burglars.
    • ;
  • discourage somebody from doing something His parents tried to discourage him from being an actor.

column5: a long and serious treatment or discussion of a subject in speech or writing
column10:
• discourse on something a discourse on issues of gender and sexuality

  • He was hoping for some lively political discourse at the meeting.

column5: the freedom or power to decide what should be done in a particular situation

• I'll leave it up to you to use your discretion.

column5: the practice of treating somebody or a particular group in society less fairly than others

• age/racial/gender/sex discrimination (= because of somebody’s age, race or sex)

  • discrimination against somebody discrimination against the elderly

  • discrimination in favour of somebody discrimination in favour of the young
    • ;
  • discrimination by somebody They alleged discrimination by the authorities.
    • ;
  • discrimination on the basis of something to prohibit/outlaw/ban discrimination on the basis of race, gender or sexual orientation
    • ;
  • discrimination on the grounds of something legislation to ban discrimination on the grounds of age

column5: the act of dismissing somebody from their job; an example of this

• He still hopes to win his claim against unfair dismissal.

column5: an illness that causes a part of the body to stop functioning correctly

• a blood/bowel disorder

  • eating disorders

  • He was suffering from some form of psychiatric disorder.

  • This is a rare disorder of the liver.
    • ;
  • Most people with acute mental disorder can be treated at home.

column5: to take the place of somebody/something
column10: • be displaced (by somebody/something) Gradually factory workers have been displaced by machines.

column5: the act of getting rid of something

• The council is responsible for waste disposal and street cleaning.

  • sewage disposal systems

column5: to arrange things or people in a particular way or position

column5: an argument between two people, groups or countries; discussion about a subject on which people disagree
column10:
• industrial/pay disputes

  • dispute between A and B a dispute between the two countries about the border

  • dispute over/about something the latest dispute over fishing rights

  • in dispute with somebody/something The union is in dispute with management over working hours.

    • ;
  • beyond dispute The matter was settled beyond dispute by the court judgment (= it could no longer be argued about).
    • ;
  • open to dispute His theories are open to dispute (= can be disagreed with).

column5: to question whether something is true or legally or officially acceptable

• dispute something These figures have been disputed.

  • to dispute a decision/claim
    • ;
  • The family wanted to dispute the will.

  • dispute that… No one is disputing that there is a problem.
    • ;
  • dispute whether, how, etc…
column11: it is disputed whether, how, etc… It is disputed whether the law applies in this case.

column5: to make it difficult for something to continue in the normal way
column10:
• Demonstrators succeeded in disrupting the meeting.
    • ;
  • Bus services will be disrupted tomorrow because of the bridge closure.

column5: a situation in which it is difficult for something to continue in the normal way; the act of stopping something from continuing in the normal way
column10:
• We aim to help you move house with minimum disruption to yourself.
    • ;
  • disruptions to rail services
    • ;
  • The strike caused serious disruptions.

column5: to mix with a liquid and become part of it
column10:
• Salt dissolves in water.
    • ;
  • Heat gently until the sugar dissolves.
    • ;
  • The aspirin hasn't dissolved completely yet.

column5: far away in space or time

• the distant sound of music
    • ;
  • distant stars/planets
    • ;
  • The time we spent together is now a distant memory.
    • ;
  • (formal) The airport was about 20 kilometres distant.
    • ;
  • a star 30 000 light years distant from the Earth
    • ;
  • (figurative) Peace was just a distant hope (= not very likely).

column5: easily or clearly heard, seen, felt, etc.

  • His voice was quiet but every word was distinct.

column5: a clear difference or contrast especially between people or things that are similar or related

• distinctions between traditional and modern societies
    • ;
  • Philosophers did not use to make a distinction between arts and science.
    • ;

column5: having a quality or characteristic that makes something different and easily noticed

• clothes with a distinctive style

  • The male bird has distinctive white markings on its head.

column5: to recognize the difference between two people or things

• distinguish between A and B At what age are children able to distinguish between right and wrong?

  • English law clearly distinguishes between murder and manslaughter.

  • distinguish A from B It was hard to distinguish one twin from the other.

column5: to change the shape, appearance or sound of something so that it is strange or not clear

• a fairground mirror that distorts your shape

column5: to take somebody’s attention away from what they are trying to do

• You're distracting me from my work.

  • Don't talk to her—she's very easily distracted.

    • ;
  • He’s easily distracted from his work
    • ;
  • an attempt to distract attention away from the real problems in the country

column5: a feeling of great worry or unhappiness; great mental pain

column5: to make somebody feel very worried or unhappy
column10:
• distress somebody It was clear that the letter had deeply distressed her.
    • ;
  • distress yourself Don't distress yourself (= don't worry).

column5: to interrupt somebody when they are trying to work, sleep, etc.

• I'm sorry to disturb you, but can I talk to you for a moment?

  • If you get up early, try not to disturb everyone else.

  • Do not disturb (= a sign placed on the outside of the door of a hotel room, office, etc.)

  • She awoke early after a disturbed night.
    • ;
  • Only the cry of seabirds disturbed the silence.

column5: making you feel anxious and upset or shocked
column10:
• a disturbing piece of news
    • ;
  • a profoundly disturbing experience

column10: • a spectacular high dive (= from high above the water)

column5: to jump into water with your head and arms going in first

• dive (from/off something) (into something) We dived into the river to cool off.
    • ;
  • dive off something He dived off the bridge.
    • ;
  • dive in Sam walked to the deep end of the pool and dived in.

column5: very different from each other and of various kinds
column10:
• People from diverse cultures were invited to the event.
    • ;
  • My interests are very diverse.

column5: a range of many people or things that are very different from each other
column10:
• the biological diversity of the rainforests
    • ;
  • a great/wide/rich diversity of opinion

• be diverted The course of the stream has now been diverted.

  • be diverted (from something) (to/into/onto something) Northbound traffic will have to be diverted onto minor roads.

• divine law/love/will

  • divine intervention (= help from God to change a situation)

  • Divorce proceedings (= the legal process of divorce) started today.

  • He remarried after a divorce from his first wife, Kate.

column5: to end your marriage to somebody legally
column10:
• They're getting divorced.
    • ;
  • She's divorcing her husband.

column5: a belief or set of beliefs held and taught by a Church, a political party, etc.

• the doctrine of parliamentary sovereignty

  • He challenged the Christian doctrine of Original Sin.
    • ;
  • He was deeply committed to political doctrines of social equality.

column5: the documents that are required for something, or that give evidence or proof of something
column10: • I couldn't enter the country because I didn't have all the necessary documentation.

column5: an area of knowledge or activity; especially one that somebody is responsible for
column10:
• Financial matters are her domain.

  • Physics used to be very much a male domain.
    • ;
  • things that happen outside the domain of the home

column5: the fact of being more important, powerful or easy to notice than somebody/something else
column10:
• political/economic dominance

  • America's rise to global dominance

  • dominance over somebody/something to achieve/assert/establish dominance over somebody

column5: more important, powerful or easy to notice than other things
column10:
• The firm has achieved a dominant position in the world market.

  • The dominant feature of the room was the large fireplace.

column5: something that is given to a person or an organization such as a charity, in order to help them; the act of giving something in this way

column5: a person or an organization that makes a gift of money, clothes, food, etc. to a charity, etc.

• international aid donors (= countries that give money, etc. to help other countries)
    • ;
  • She is one of the charity's main donors.

column5: an amount of a medicine or a drug that is taken once, or regularly over a period of time

• a high/low/lethal dose
    • ;
  • Repeat the dose after 12 hours if necessary.
    • ;
  • Take a single dose at bedtime to help you sleep.
    • ;
  • I always take my daily dose of vitamin C.

column5: a small round mark, especially one that is printed

• There are dots above the letters i and j.
    • ;
  • Text and graphics are printed at 300 dots per inch.
    • ;
  • The helicopters appeared as two black dots on the horizon.
    • ;
  • The island is a small green dot on the map.

column5: in, towards or typical of the centre of a city, especially its main business area

column5: in or towards the centre of a city, especially its main business area
column10: • to go/work downtown

column5: the centre of a city, especially its main business area
column10: • a hotel in the heart of downtown

column5: to make something empty or dry by removing the liquid from it; to become empty or dry in this way
column10:
• Drain and rinse the pasta.

  • The marshes have been drained.
    • ;
  • You will need to drain the central heating system before you replace the radiator.
    • ;
  • The swimming pool drains very slowly.
    • ;
  • Leave the dishes to drain.

column5: very suddenly and to a very great and often surprising degree
column10:
• Prices have fallen dramatically.
    • ;
  • Prices have increased dramatically in the last few years.
    • ;
  • Events could have developed in a dramatically different way.
    • ;
  • Since then the situation has changed dramatically.

column5: to move along smoothly and slowly in water or air

• Clouds drifted across the sky.
    • ;
  • The empty boat drifted out to sea.
    • ;
  • A cool breeze drifted through the open window.
    • ;
  • Smoke drifted across the room.

column5: strong and powerful; having a strong influence in making something happen
column10:
• Who was the driving force (= the person with the strongest influence) in the band?

  • She only got where she is today through hard work and a driving ambition.

column5: a long period of time when there is little or no rain
column10:
• Farmers are facing ruin after two years of severe drought.
    • ;
  • one of the worst droughts on record
    • ;
  • The country’s entire grain harvest has been hit by drought.

column5: to die because you have been underwater too long and you cannot breathe; to kill somebody by holding them underwater
column10:
• Two children drowned after falling into the river.
    • ;
  • He had attempted to rescue the drowning man.
    • ;
  • drown somebody/something/yourself She tried to drown herself.
    • ;
  • They had drowned the unwanted kittens.
    • ;
  • be drowned He was drowned at sea.

column5: having two parts or aspects
column10:
• his dual role as composer and conductor

  • She has dual nationality (= is a citizen of two different countries).

column5: to give somebody/something a particular name, often in a humorous or critical way

• The media dubbed anorexia ‘the slimming disease’.

  • Genetically modified products have been dubbed ‘Frankenfoods’ in the popular press.

column5: not interesting or exciting

• Life in a small town could be deadly dull.

  • The countryside was flat, dull and uninteresting.

  • The first half of the game was pretty dull.

column5: stupid
column10:
• That was a pretty dumb thing to do.

  • If the police question you, act dumb (= pretend you do not know anything).
