  • In her early movies she played a dumb blonde.

column5: to get rid of something you do not want, especially in a place that is not suitable
column10:
• Too much toxic waste is being dumped at sea.
    • ;
  • The dead body was just dumped by the roadside.
    • ;
  • Any vessel dumping at sea without a licence will be prosecuted.

column5: two people who perform together or are often seen or thought of together
column10:
• the comedy duo Laurel and Hardy
    • ;
  • the goal-scoring duo of Coates and Winterbotham

column5: the length of time that something lasts or continues
column10:
• The school was used as a hospital for the duration of the war.
    • ;
  • a contract of three years’ duration

column5: having a lot of energy and a strong personality
column10:
• a dynamic leader
    • ;
  • He was a dynamic young advertising executive.
    • ;
  • She has a dynamic personality.

column5: the way in which people or things behave and react to each other in a particular situation
column10:
• the dynamics of political change
    • ;
  • group dynamics (= the way in which members of a group react to each other)
    • ;
  • Market dynamics are working in the company’s favour.

column5: very interested and excited by something that is going to happen or about something that you want to do; showing this
column10:
• eager crowds outside the stadium
    • ;
  • Small eager faces looked up and listened.
    • ;
  • eager for something She is eager for (= wants very much to get) her parents' approval.
    • ;
  • eager to do something Everyone in the class seemed eager to learn.
    • ;
  • They're eager to please (= wanting to be helpful).

column5: the money that you earn for the work that you do
column10:
• a rise in average earnings
    • ;
  • She is claiming compensation for loss of earnings.

column5: lack of difficulty
column10:
• with ease He passed the exam with ease.
    • ;
  • The ease with which she learns languages is astonishing.
    • ;
  • for ease of something All important points are numbered for ease of reference (= so that you can find them easily).
    • ;
  • This computer is popular for its good design and ease of use.

column5: to become less unpleasant, painful or severe; to make something less unpleasant, etc.
column10:
• The pain immediately eased.
    • ;
  • ease something This should help ease the pain.
    • ;
  • The plan should ease traffic congestion in the town.
    • ;
  • It would ease my mind (= make me less worried) to know that she was settled.

column5: the reflecting of sound off a wall or inside a particular space so that a noise appears to be repeated; a sound that is reflected back in this way
column10:
• There was an echo on the phone and I couldn't hear clearly.
    • ;
  • The hills sent back a faint echo.
    • ;
  • the echo of footsteps running down the corridor
    • ;
  • ‘So you love him, do you?’ Magda’s voice was a mocking echo of my own.

column5: if a sound echoes, it is reflected off a wall, the side of a mountain, etc. so that you can hear it again
column10:
• Her footsteps echoed in the empty room.
    • ;
  • The gunshot echoed through the forest.

column5: connected with the relation of plants and living creatures to each other and to their environment
column10:
• We risk upsetting the ecological balance of the area.
    • ;
  • an ecological disaster (= one that alters the whole balance of ecology in an area)

column5: the study of how a society organizes its money, trade and industry
column10:
• He studied politics and economics at Yale.
    • ;
  • Keynesian/Marxist economics
    • ;
  • trends in modern economics

column5: a person who studies or writes about economics
column10:
• the World Bank's chief economist
    • ;
  • Many economists are predicting the economy will improve.

column5: connected with the task of preparing something such as a newspaper, a book or a television or radio programme, to be published or broadcast
column10:
• the magazine’s editorial staff
    • ;
  • Some debates in Parliament are shown live and are outside editorial control.
    • ;
  • The paper follows an editorial policy that puts great emphasis on foreign news.
    • ;
  • an editorial decision

column5: a person whose job is to teach or educate people
column10: • adult educators (= who teach adults)

column5: the fact of producing the result that is wanted or intended; the fact of producing a successful result
column10: • to check the effectiveness of the security system

column5: the quality of doing something well with no waste of time or money
column10:
• improvements in efficiency at the factory
    • ;
  • I was impressed by the efficiency with which she handled the crisis.

column5: in a good and careful way, with no waste of time, money or energy
column10:
• a very efficiently organized event
    • ;
  • Resources must be used efficiently to avoid waste.
    • ;
  • If markets fail or do not work efficiently, government has a role to play.

column5: your sense of your own value and importance
column10:
• He has the biggest ego of anyone I've ever met.
    • ;
  • Winning the prize really boosted her ego.

column5: very complicated and detailed; carefully prepared and organized
column10:
• elaborate designs
    • ;
  • She had prepared a very elaborate meal.
    • ;
  • an elaborate computer system

column5: the joint between the upper and lower parts of the arm where it bends in the middle
column10:
• She jabbed him with her elbow.
    • ;
  • He rested his elbows on his knees.
    • ;
  • She grazed her elbow in the fall.
    • ;
  • He's fractured his elbow.

column5: connected with elections
column10: • electoral systems/reforms

column5: the branch of science and technology that studies electric currents in electronic equipment
column10:
• the electronics industry
    • ;
  • About 45 000 people worked in electronics in Scotland.
    • ;
  • Their company merged with a Japanese electronics giant.

column5: attractive and showing a good sense of style
column10:
• She was tall and elegant.
    • ;
  • The diners all looked effortlessly elegant.
    • ;
  • He cut an elegant figure in a dark suit.

column5: in or connected with the first stages of a course of study
column10:
• an elementary English course
    • ;
  • a book for elementary students
    • ;
  • at an elementary level
    • ;
  • I'm taking classes in elementary Italian.

column5: to give somebody/something a higher position or rank, often more important than they deserve
column10:
• elevate somebody/something (to something) He elevated many of his friends to powerful positions within the government.
    • ;
  • elevate something (into/to something) It was an attempt to elevate football to a subject worthy of serious study.
    • ;
  • He has elevated bad taste into an art form.

column5: a person who is eligible for something or to do something, is able to have or do it because they have the right qualifications, are the right age, etc.
column10:
• eligible (for something) Only those over 70 are eligible for the special payment.
    • ;
  • The new regulations made a lot of prisoners eligible for early release.
    • ;
  • You are not considered eligible for legal aid.
    • ;
  • eligible (to do something) When are you eligible to vote in your country?

column5: to remove or get rid of something
column10:
• eliminate something Credit cards eliminate the need to carry a lot of cash.
    • ;
  • eliminate something from something This diet claims to eliminate toxins from the body.

column5: a small group of people in a society, etc. who are powerful and have a lot of influence, because they are rich, intelligent, etc.
column10:
• a member of the ruling/intellectual elite
    • ;
  • Public opinion is influenced by the small elite who control the media.
    • ;
  • In these countries, only the elite can afford an education for their children.

column5: to get onto a ship or plane; to put somebody/something onto a ship or plane
column10:
• We stood on the pier and watched as they embarked.
    • ;
  • embark somebody/something They embarked the troops by night.

column5: shy, uncomfortable or guilty feelings; a feeling of being embarrassed
column10:
• I nearly died of embarrassment when he said that.
    • ;
  • embarrassment of (doing) something I'm glad you offered—it saved me the embarrassment of having to ask.
    • ;
  • to somebody's embarrassment Much to her embarrassment, she realized that everybody had been listening to her singing.

column5: a group of officials led by an ambassador who represent their government in a foreign country
column10:
• embassy officials
    • ;
  • to inform the embassy of the situation

column5: to fix something in a substance or solid object
column10:
• be embedded in something an operation to remove glass that was embedded in his leg
    • ;
  • (figurative) These attitudes are deeply embedded in our society (= felt very strongly and difficult to change).
    • ;
  • embed something/itself (in something) The bullet embedded itself in the wall.

column5: to express or represent an idea or a quality
column10:
• embody something a politician who embodied the hopes of black youth
    • ;
  • be embodied in something the principles embodied in the Declaration of Human Rights

column5: to put your arms around somebody as a sign of love or friendship
column10:
• They embraced and promised to keep in touch.
    • ;
  • embrace somebody She embraced her son warmly.
    • ;
  • He rose from his chair and embraced her warmly.

column5: the fact of somebody/something moving out of or away from something and becoming possible to see
column10:
• the island’s emergence from the sea 3 000 years ago
    • ;
  • Albania's emergence from its long period of isolation

column5: the production or sending out of light, heat, gas, etc.
column10:
• the emission of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere
    • ;
  • emission controls

column5: in a way that is connected with people's feelings (= with the emotions)
column10:
• emotionally disturbed children
    • ;
  • I try not to become emotionally involved.
    • ;
  • They have suffered physically and emotionally.

column5: a group of countries or states that are controlled by one leader or government
column10: • These invasions almost led to the collapse of the Roman Empire.

column5: based on experiments or experience rather than ideas or theories
column10:
• empirical evidence/knowledge/research
    • ;
  • an empirical study

column5: to give somebody the power or authority to do something
column10: • be empowered (to do something) The courts were empowered to impose the death sentence for certain crimes.

column5: to pass a law
column10: • (be) enacted (by somebody/something) legislation enacted by parliament

column5: to include a large number or range of things
column10:
• The job encompasses a wide range of responsibilities.
    • ;
  • The group encompasses all ages.

column5: the act of encouraging somebody to do something; something that encourages somebody
column10:
• a few words of encouragement
    • ;
  • He needs all the support and encouragement he can get.
    • ;
  • With a little encouragement from his parents he should do well.
    • ;
  • encouragement (to somebody) (to do something) She was given every encouragement to try something new.
    • ;
  • Her words were a great encouragement to them.

column5: that gives somebody support, courage or hope
column10:
• This month's unemployment figures are not very encouraging.
    • ;
  • You could try being a little more encouraging!
    • ;
  • Despite the encouraging findings, we remain cautious.

column5: an attempt to do something, especially something new or difficult
column10:
• There have been great advances in the field of scientific endeavour.
    • ;
  • endeavour to do something Please make every endeavour to arrive on time.
    • ;
  • The manager is expected to use his or her best endeavours to promote the artist's career.
    • ;
  • in an endeavour to do something The public bombarded the company with complaints in an endeavour to have the price increases revoked.

column5: very large in size or amount and seeming to have no end
column10:
• endless patience
    • ;
  • endless opportunities for making money
    • ;
  • The possibilities are endless.
    • ;
  • an endless list of things to do
    • ;
  • We don't have an endless supply of money, you know.
    • ;
  • I've had enough of their endless arguing.

column5: to say publicly that you support a person, statement or course of action
column10:
• I wholeheartedly endorse his remarks.
    • ;
  • Members of all parties endorsed a ban on land mines.

column5: a public statement or action showing that you support somebody/something
column10:
• The election victory is a clear endorsement of their policies.
    • ;
  • a letter of endorsement
    • ;
  • This is hardly a ringing endorsement of the plan.

column5: to experience and deal with something that is painful or unpleasant without giving up
column10:
• endure something They had to endure a long wait before the case came to trial.
    • ;
  • She could not endure the thought of parting.
    • ;
  • The pain was almost too great to endure.
    • ;
  • (formal) a love that endures all things and never fails
    • ;
  • He had to endure the racist taunts of the crowd.
    • ;
  • endure doing something He can't endure being defeated.
    • ;
  • endure to do something He can't endure to be defeated.

column5: to make sure that people obey a particular law or rule
column10:
• enforce something It's the job of the police to enforce the law.
    • ;
  • The legislation will be difficult to enforce.
    • ;
  • United Nations troops enforced a ceasefire in the area.
    • ;
  • enforce something against/on somebody/something (formal or law) The creditor should be at liberty to enforce his rights against the company's property.

column5: the act of making people obey a particular law or rule
column10:
• strict enforcement of regulations
    • ;
  • law enforcement officers

column5: an agreement to marry somebody; the period during which two people are engaged
column10:
• Their engagement was announced in the local paper.
    • ;
  • engagement (to somebody) She has broken off her engagement to Charles.
    • ;
  • an engagement party
    • ;
  • a long/short engagement
    • ;
  • He announced his engagement to his long-time girlfriend.

column5: interesting or pleasant in a way that attracts your attention
column10: • an engaging smile

column5: giving pleasure
column10:
• an enjoyable weekend/experience
    • ;
  • highly/really/thoroughly/very enjoyable

column5: to ask somebody for some information
column10:
• enquire about somebody/something I called the station to enquire about train times.
    • ;
  • enquire as to somebody/something She enquired as to your whereabouts.
    • ;
  • enquire why, where, etc… Might I enquire why you have not mentioned this until now?
    • ;
  • enquire something He enquired her name.
    • ;
  • + speech ‘What is your name?’ he enquired.

column5: to improve the quality of something, often by adding something to it
column10: • The study of science has enriched all our lives.

column5: to arrange for yourself or for somebody else to officially join a course, school, etc.
column10:
• You need to enrol before the end of August.
    • ;
  • (British English) to enrol on a course
    • ;
  • (North American English) to enroll in a course
    • ;
  • enrol somebody The centre will soon be ready to enrol candidates for the new programme.

column5: to happen after or as a result of another event
column10:
• An argument ensued.
    • ;
  • The riot police swooped in and chaos ensued.

column5: a company or business
column10:
• He is in charge of an enterprise with a turnover of $26 billion.
    • ;
  • state-owned/public enterprises
    • ;
  • The grant is available to small and medium-sized enterprises.

column5: that you enjoy watching, listening to, doing or experiencing
column10:
• an entertaining speech/evening
    • ;
  • I found the talk both informative and entertaining.
    • ;
  • She was always so funny and entertaining.

column5: a person who is very interested in something and spends a lot of time doing it
column10:
• a football enthusiast
    • ;
  • enthusiast of something an enthusiast of jazz
    • ;
  • enthusiast for something She was an enthusiast for early Italian art.

column5: to give somebody the right to have or to do something
column10:
• be entitled to something You will be entitled to your pension when you reach 65.
    • ;
  • Everyone's entitled to their own opinion.
    • ;
  • entitle somebody to do something This ticket does not entitle you to travel first class.

column5: something that exists separately from other things and has its own identity
column10:
• The unit has become part of a larger department and no longer exists as a separate entity.
    • ;
  • These countries can no longer be viewed as a single entity.
    • ;
  • Hip hop is a major commercial entity now (= it is a business, not just a type of music).
    • ;
  • A corporation is a separate legal entity and it shields you from personal liability for its debts.

column5: a person who makes money by starting or running businesses, especially when this involves taking financial risks
column10:
• A creative entrepreneur, he was continually dreaming up new projects.
    • ;
  • a recent MBA graduate and budding entrepreneur

column5: a flat paper container used for sending letters in, with a part that you stick down to close it
column10:
• Writing paper and envelopes are provided in your room.
    • ;
  • a padded/prepaid envelope

column5: a large number of cases of a particular disease or medical condition happening at the same time in a particular community
column10:
• the outbreak of a flu epidemic
    • ;
  • An epidemic of measles broke out, and over 200 children died.
    • ;
  • Effectively, tobacco companies will be exporting an epidemic of smoking-related diseases, the campaign suggests.

column5: the fact of being equal in rights, status, advantages, etc.
column10:
• racial/social/gender equality
    • ;
  • We need to ensure equality of opportunity in all areas of work.
    • ;
  • the principle of equality before the law (= the law treats everyone the same)
    • ;
  • Don't you believe in equality between men and women?

column5: a statement showing that two amounts or values are equal, for example 2x + y = 54
column10:
• the numbers on the right-hand side of the equation
    • ;
  • the equation for a straight line

column5: to provide yourself/somebody/something with the things that are needed for a particular purpose or activity
column10:
• equip something to be fully/poorly equipped
    • ;
  • She got a bank loan to rent and equip a small workshop.
    • ;
  • equip yourself/somebody/something (with something) (for something) He equipped himself with a street plan.
    • ;
  • be equipped for/with something The centre is well equipped for canoeing and mountaineering.
    • ;
  • Rooms vary in size and come equipped with hairdryers, television and telephone.

column5: equal in value, amount, meaning, importance, etc.
column10:
• 250 grams or an equivalent amount in ounces
    • ;
  • the price we would pay elsewhere for a broadly equivalent house
    • ;
  • equivalent to something Eight kilometres is roughly equivalent to five miles.
    • ;
  • The new regulation was seen as equivalent to censorship.

column5: a thing, amount, word, etc. that is equal in value, meaning or purpose to something else
column10:
• Send €20 or the equivalent in your own currency.
    • ;
  • equivalent of something the modern equivalent of the Roman baths
    • ;
  • Is there a French word that is the exact equivalent of the English word ‘home’?
    • ;
  • equivalent of doing something Breathing such polluted air is the equivalent of (= has the same effect as) smoking ten cigarettes a day.
    • ;
  • equivalent to something The German ‘Gymnasium’ is the closest equivalent to the grammar school in England.

column5: a period of time, usually in history, that is different from other periods because of particular characteristics or events
column10:
• the Victorian/modern/post-war era
    • ;
  • When she left the firm, it was the end of an era (= things were different after that).
    • ;
  • This is the start of a new era of peace and prosperity.

column5: to build something
column10: • The church was erected in 1582.

column5: when a volcano erupts or burning rocks, smoke, etc. erupt or are erupted, the burning rocks, etc. are thrown out from the volcano
column10:
• The volcano could erupt at any time.
    • ;
  • erupt from something Ash began to erupt from the crater.
    • ;
  • erupt something An immense volume of rocks and molten lava was erupted.

column5: to become greater, worse, more serious, etc.; to make something greater, worse, more serious, etc.
column10:
• the escalating costs of healthcare
    • ;
  • escalate into something The fighting escalated into a full-scale war.
    • ;
  • escalate something (into something) We do not want to escalate the war.

column5: the most important quality or feature of something, that makes it what it is
column10:
• His paintings capture the essence of France.
    • ;
  • in essence In essence (= when you consider the most important points), your situation isn't so different from mine.

column5: when you think about the true, important or basic nature of somebody/something
column10:
• There are three essentially different ways of tackling the problem.
    • ;
  • The pattern is essentially the same in all cases.
    • ;
  • Essentially, what we are suggesting is that the firm needs to change.
    • ;
  • He was, essentially, a teacher, not a manager.
    • ;
  • The article was essentially concerned with her relationship with her parents (= it dealt with other things, but this was the most important).

column5: an organization, a large institution or a hotel
column10:
• The visa is for foreign nationals wishing to study at a university, college or similar educational establishment.
    • ;
  • She's now running a small government research establishment.
    • ;
  • The hotel is a comfortable and well-run establishment.

column5: without an end; existing or continuing forever
column10:
• the promise of eternal life in heaven
    • ;
  • She's an eternal optimist (= she always expects that the best will happen).
    • ;
  • eternal truths (= ideas that are always true and never change)
    • ;
  • You have my eternal gratitude (= very great gratitude).
    • ;
  • To his eternal credit (= very great credit), he never gave up.
    • ;
  • Newspapers are simply responding to the eternal fascination of their readers with the private lives of the rich and famous.

column5: moral principles that control or influence a person’s behaviour
column10:
• professional/business/medical ethics
    • ;
  • to draw up a code of ethics
    • ;
  • He began to question the ethics of his position.

column5: connected with or belonging to a group of people that share a cultural tradition
column10:
• ethnic background/origin
    • ;
  • ethnic strife/tensions/violence (= between different ethnic groups)
    • ;
  • Our government should reflect the racial and ethnic diversity of our country.
    • ;
  • ethnic Albanians living in Germany
    • ;
  • The country is divided along ethnic lines.

column5: to move people from a place of danger to a safer place
column10:
• evacuate something Police evacuated nearby buildings.
    • ;
  • evacuate somebody (from…) (to…) Children were evacuated from London to escape the bombing.
    • ;
  • Families were evacuated to safer parts of the city.

column5: the act of forming an opinion of the amount, value or quality of something after thinking about it carefully
column10:
• an evaluation of the healthcare system
    • ;
  • The technique is not widely practised and requires further evaluation.
    • ;
  • The discussion includes a critical evaluation of the documentary sources.

column5: clear; easily seen
column10:
• The orchestra played with evident enjoyment.
    • ;
  • evident (to somebody) (that…) It has now become evident to us that a mistake has been made.
    • ;
  • evident in/from something The growing interest in history is clearly evident in the number of people visiting museums and country houses.

column5: to bring a feeling, a memory or an image into your mind
column10:
• The music evoked memories of her youth.
    • ;
  • His case is unlikely to evoke public sympathy.

column5: the slow steady development of plants, animals, etc. during the history of the earth, as they adapt to changes in their environment
column10:
• the evolution of the human species
    • ;
  • Darwin’s theory of evolution
    • ;
  • Finally it was legal to teach evolution everywhere in America.

column5: connected with evolution; connected with slow steady development and change
column10:
• evolutionary theory
    • ;
  • evolutionary change

column5: to develop gradually, especially from a simple to a more complicated form; to develop something in this way
column10:
• evolve (from something) (into something) The idea evolved from a drawing I discovered in the attic.
    • ;
  • The company has evolved into a major chemical manufacturer.
    • ;
  • evolve something (from something) Each school must evolve its own way of working.

column5: to make something seem larger, better, worse or more important than it really is
column10:
• The hotel was really filthy and I'm not exaggerating.
    • ;
  • exaggerate something He tends to exaggerate the difficulties.
    • ;
  • I'm sure he exaggerates his Irish accent (= tries to sound more Irish than he really is).
    • ;
  • Demand for the product has been greatly exaggerated.

column5: to be greater than a particular number or amount
column10: • The price will not exceed £100.

column5: the quality of being extremely good
column10:
• a reputation for academic excellence
    • ;
  • excellence in something The hospital is recognized as a centre of excellence in research and teaching.

column5: a person or thing that is not included in a general statement
column10:
• Most of the buildings in the town are modern, but the church is an exception.
    • ;
  • With very few exceptions, private schools get the best exam results.
    • ;
  • Nobody had much money at the time and I was no exception.

column5: unusually good
column10:
• At the age of five he showed exceptional talent as a musician.
    • ;
  • The quality of the recording is quite exceptional.

column5: in addition to an amount that is necessary, usual or legal
column10:
• Excess food is stored as fat.
    • ;
  • Driving with excess alcohol in the blood is a serious offence.
    • ;
  • The book is hard to obtain, because of excess demand following the author’s appearance on TV.

column5: more than is necessary, reasonable or acceptable
column10:
• You can throw away any excess.
    • ;
  • excess of something Are you suffering from an excess of stress in your life?
    • ;
  • In an excess of enthusiasm I agreed to work late.
    • ;
  • to excess He started drinking to excess after losing his job.
    • ;
  • in excess of something The increase will not be in excess of (= more than) two per cent.

column5: greater than what seems reasonable or appropriate
column10:
• They complained about the excessive noise coming from the upstairs flat.
    • ;
  • The amounts she borrowed were not excessive.
    • ;
  • Excessive drinking can lead to stomach disorders.
    • ;
  • He claimed that the police had used excessive force.

column5: to deliberately not include something in what you are doing or considering
column10:
• The cost of borrowing has been excluded from the inflation figures.
    • ;
  • Try excluding fat from your diet.
    • ;
  • Buses run every hour, Sundays excluded.

column5: the act of preventing somebody/something from entering a place or taking part in something
column10:
• exclusion (of somebody/something) (from something) He was disappointed with his exclusion from the England squad.
    • ;
  • Exclusion of air creates a vacuum in the bottle.
    • ;
  • to the exclusion of something Memories of the past filled her mind to the exclusion of all else.

column5: only to be used by one particular person or group; only given to one particular person or group
column10:
• The hotel has exclusive access to the beach.
    • ;
  • exclusive rights to televise the World Cup
    • ;
  • His mother has told ‘The Times’ about his death in an exclusive interview (= not given to any other newspaper).

column5: for only one particular person, group or use
column10:
• The resort caters almost exclusively for a high-society public.
    • ;
  • Some products are labelled exclusively for indoor or outdoor use.

column5: to kill somebody, especially as a legal punishment
column10:
• be executed (for something) He was executed for treason.
    • ;
  • be executed by something The prisoners were executed by firing squad.

column5: the act of killing somebody, especially as a legal punishment
column10:
• He faced execution by hanging for murder.
    • ;
  • Over 200 executions were carried out last year.

column5: to use power or influence to affect somebody/something
column10:
• He exerted all his authority to make them accept the plan.
    • ;
  • The moon exerts a force on the earth that causes the tides.

column5: an object or a collection of objects put in a public place, for example a museum, so that people can see it
column10: • The museum contains some interesting exhibits on Spanish rural life.

column5: to show something in a public place for people to enjoy or to give them information
column10:
• exhibit something (at/in…) They will be exhibiting their new designs at the trade fairs.
    • ;
  • Only one painting was exhibited in the artist's lifetime.
    • ;
  • He longed for the chance to exhibit his work publicly.
    • ;
  • exhibit (at/in…) He exhibits regularly in local art galleries.

column5: the state of being sent to live in another country that is not your own, especially for political reasons or as a punishment
column10:
• a place of exile
    • ;
  • He returned after 40 years of exile.
    • ;
  • in exile He has lived in exile since 1989.
    • ;
  • into exile The whole family went into exile.
    • ;
  • to be forced/sent into exile
    • ;
  • in exile from… Dante died in exile from Florence.

column5: a way out of a public building or vehicle
column10:
• Where's the exit?
    • ;
  • There is a fire exit on each floor of the building.
    • ;
  • The emergency exit is at the back of the bus.

column5: to go out; to leave a building, stage, vehicle, etc.
column10:
• (+ adv./prep.) The bullet entered her back and exited through her chest.
    • ;
  • We exited via a fire door.
    • ;
  • exit something As the actors exited the stage the lights went on.

column5: from or in another country, especially a tropical one; seeming exciting and unusual because it seems to be connected with foreign countries
column10:
• brightly-coloured exotic flowers/plants/birds
    • ;
  • She travels to all kinds of exotic locations all over the world.
    • ;
  • The fruits sound exotic. Do they taste good?

column5: an act of increasing or making something increase in size, amount or importance
column10:
• a period of rapid economic expansion
    • ;
  • Despite the recession the company is confident of further expansion.
    • ;
  • The expansion of higher education will continue.
    • ;
  • The book is an expansion of a series of lectures given last year.

column5: the act of spending or using money; an amount of money spent
column10:
• a reduction in public/government/military expenditure
    • ;
  • plans to increase expenditure on health
    • ;
  • The budget provided for a total expenditure of £27 billion.
    • ;
  • Savings have been disposed of in order to meet the growing gap between income and expenditure.

column5: based on new ideas, forms or methods that are used to find out what effect they have
column10:
• The school's experimental teaching methods include letting the children decide what to study.
    • ;
  • experimental theatre/art/music
    • ;
  • The equipment is still at the experimental stage.
    • ;
  • Doctors stress that this kind of treatment is still experimental.

column5: expert knowledge or skill in a particular subject, activity or job
column10:
• professional/scientific/technical, etc. expertise
    • ;
  • We have the expertise to help you run your business.
    • ;
  • It is difficult to find staff with the level of expertise required for this job.
    • ;
  • expertise in something/in doing something They have considerable expertise in dealing with oil spills.

column5: to be no longer legally acceptable because the period of time for which it could be used has ended
column10:
• When does your driving licence expire?
    • ;
  • Our lease on the house expires next month.

column5: clear and easy to understand, so that you have no doubt what is meant
column10:
• He gave me very explicit directions on how to get there.
    • ;
  • The reasons for the decision should be made explicit.
    • ;
  • She made some very explicit references to my personal life.

column5: clearly or directly, so that the meaning is easy to understand
column10:
• The report states explicitly that the system was to blame.
    • ;
  • The text does not explicitly mention him by name.

column5: to treat a person or situation as an opportunity to gain an advantage for yourself
column10:
• He exploited his father's name to get himself a job.
    • ;
  • She realized that her youth and inexperience were being exploited.
    • ;
  • The opposition parties will always exploit government problems to their own advantage.

column5: a situation in which somebody treats somebody else in an unfair way, especially in order to make money from their work
column10:
• the exploitation of children
    • ;
  • Starvation and poverty are the result of global economic exploitation, not lack of resources.

column5: easily able or likely to explode
column10:
• an explosive device (= a bomb)
    • ;
  • an explosive mixture of chemicals
    • ;
  • Hydrogen is highly explosive.

column5: a substance that is able or likely to cause an explosion
column10:
• plastic explosives
    • ;
  • The bomb was packed with several pounds of high explosive.

column5: the state of being in a place or situation where there is no protection from something harmful or unpleasant
column10:
• prolonged exposure to harmful radiation
    • ;
  • At high exposures, the chemical can affect the liver and kidneys.
    • ;
  • (finance) the company’s exposure on the foreign exchange markets (= to the risk of making financial losses)

column5: the act of increasing the area of activity, group of people, etc. that is affected by something
column10:
• the extension of new technology into developing countries
    • ;
  • a gradual extension of the powers of central government
    • ;
  • The bank plans various extensions to its credit facilities.
    • ;
  • My home life was becoming no more than an extension of my job.

column5: covering a large area; great in amount
column10:
• The house has extensive grounds.
    • ;
  • The fire caused extensive damage.
    • ;
  • She suffered extensive injuries in the accident.
    • ;
  • Extensive repair work is being carried out.
    • ;
  • an extensive range of wines
    • ;
  • The book includes an extensive bibliography of books and articles.

column5: in a way that covers a large area
column10: • She has travelled extensively.

column5: a short passage from a book, piece of music, etc. that gives you an idea of what the whole thing is like
column10: • The following extract is taken from her new novel.

column5: to remove or obtain a substance from something, for example by using an industrial or a chemical process
column10:
• a machine that extracts excess moisture from the air
    • ;
  • The Egyptians used a primitive form of distillation to extract the essential oils from plants.
    • ;
  • Animals take in food and extract nutrients from it.

column5: a person whose opinions, especially about religion or politics, are extreme, and who may do things that are violent or illegal for what they believe
column10:
• left-wing/right-wing/political/religious extremists
    • ;
  • He was assassinated by extremists.

column5: material made by weaving wool, cotton, silk, etc., used for making clothes, curtains, etc. and for covering furniture
column10:
• They sell a wide variety of printed cotton fabric.
    • ;
  • furnishing fabrics

column5: extremely good
column10:
• They put on a fabulous performance.
    • ;
  • Jana is a fabulous cook.
    • ;
  • The food looks fabulous.
    • ;
  • I want an outfit that'll make me look fabulous.

column5: to make an action or a process possible or easier
column10:
• The new trade agreement should facilitate more rapid economic growth.
    • ;
  • Structured teaching facilitates learning.

column5: a small group of people within a larger one, whose members have some different aims and beliefs to those of the larger group
column10: • There are rival factions within the administration.

column5: a department or group of related departments in a college or university
column10:
• the Faculty of Law
    • ;
  • students who are doing degrees in the Arts Faculty
    • ;
  • the Faculty of Arts

column5: to become or to make something become paler or less bright
column10:
• The curtains had faded in the sun.
    • ;
  • fade from something All colour had faded from the sky.
    • ;
  • fade something The sun had faded the curtains.
    • ;
  • He was wearing faded blue jeans.

column5: not successful
column10:
• a failed writer
    • ;
  • a failed coup

column5: the quality of treating people equally or in a way that is reasonable
column10:
• The fairness of the judicial system is being questioned.
    • ;
  • She has a strong sense of justice and fairness.

column5: not what somebody claims it is; appearing to be something it is not
column10:
• There were a few stalls selling fake designer clothing.

  • The caller appeared to have a fake American accent.

column5: the state of being known and talked about by many people

• to achieve/win instant fame
    • ;
  • Daisy Ridley of ‘Star Wars’ fame (= famous for ‘Star Wars’)

  • The town's only claim to fame is that there was once a riot there.
    • ;
  • She went to Hollywood in search of fame and fortune.

column5: a pleasant situation that you imagine but that is unlikely to happen
column10: • He spoke of his childhood fantasies about becoming a famous football player.

column5: the money that you pay to travel by bus, plane, taxi, etc.
column10:
• bus/taxi fares
    • ;
  • train/rail fares
    • ;
  • Children travel (at) half fare.
    • ;
  • When do they start paying full fare?

column5: causing or ending in death
column10:
• a fatal accident/blow/illness
    • ;
  • a potentially fatal form of cancer
    • ;
  • If she gets ill again it could prove fatal.

column5: the things, especially bad things, that will happen or have happened to somebody/something
column10:
• The fate of the three men is unknown.
    • ;
  • She sat outside, waiting to find out her fate.
    • ;
  • The court will decide our fate/fates.
    • ;
  • Each of the managers suffered the same fate.
    • ;
  • He warned about the scam so others could avoid a similar fate.
    • ;
  • Inhabitants of war-torn areas have been abandoned to their fate.
    • ;
  • From that moment our fate was sealed (= our future was decided).

column5: making people have a good opinion of somebody/something
column10:
• She made a favourable impression on his parents.
    • ;
  • The biography shows him in a favourable light.
    • ;
  • She gained a highly favourable impression of the company.

column5: an action or a piece of work that needs skill, strength or courage
column10:
• The tunnel is a remarkable feat of engineering.
    • ;
  • to accomplish/achieve/perform astonishing feats
    • ;
  • That was no mean feat (= it was difficult to do).

column5: having a system of government in which the individual states of a country have control over their own affairs, but are controlled by a central government for national decisions, etc.
column10: • a federal republic

column5: having or based on the belief that women should have the same rights and opportunities as men
column10:
• feminist demands/ideas/theories
    • ;
  • the feminist movement

column5: a person who supports the belief that women should have the same rights and opportunities as men
column10: • Nineteenth-century feminists demanded equal education and employment opportunities for single women.

column5: a medical condition in which a person has a temperature that is higher than normal
column10:
• He has a high fever.
    • ;
  • Aspirin should help reduce the fever.

column5: the part of food that helps to keep a person healthy by keeping the bowels working and moving other food quickly through the body
column10:
• dietary fibre
    • ;
  • Dried fruits are especially high in fibre.

  • a high-/low-fibre diet
    • ;
  • He has been advised to increase his fibre intake.
    • ;
  • bran fibre

column5: angry and aggressive in a way that is frightening
column10:
• a fierce dog
    • ;
  • Two fierce eyes glared at them.
    • ;
  • He suddenly looked fierce.
    • ;
  • She spoke in a fierce whisper.
    • ;
  • The more she struggled, the fiercer he became.

column5: a person who directs or produces films
a device containing paper, sand, chemicals, etc. that a liquid or gas is passed through in order to remove any materials that are not wanted
column10:
• an air/oil filter
    • ;
  • a coffee/water filter
    • ;
  • filter paper for the coffee machine
    • ;
  • He smokes cigarettes without filters.

column5: to pass liquid, light, etc. through a special device, especially to remove something that is not wanted
column10:
• All drinking water must be filtered.
    • ;
  • Use a sun block that filters UVA effectively.
    • ;
  • (figurative) My secretary is very good at filtering my calls (= making sure that calls that I do not want do not get through).

column5: a sum of money that must be paid as punishment for breaking a law or rule
column10:
• I got a parking fine for parking on double yellow lines.

  • Offenders will be liable to a heavy fine (= one that costs a lot of money).
    • ;
  • Under the new law, motorists face fines of up to £1 000.
    • ;
  • She has already paid over $2 000 in fines.

column5: to make somebody pay money as an official punishment
column10:
• fine somebody (something) The magistrate fined him $400.
    • ;
  • be fined (something) Any company found to be breaking these rules will be heavily fined.
    • ;
  • be fined for (doing) something She was fined for speeding.
    • ;
  • be fined something for (doing) something The company was fined £20 000 for breaching safety regulations.
    • ;
  • He got fined £200 for parking illegally.

column5: a gun that can be carried
column10: • The police were issued with firearms.

column5: a person whose job is to put out fires
column10:
• Firefighters were called to a house in Summertown.

  • Firefighters rescued a driver trapped in the wreckage of his car.

column5: a small device containing powder that burns or explodes and produces bright coloured lights and loud noises, used especially at celebrations
column10:
• (British English) to let off a few fireworks

  • (North American English) to set off a few fireworks
    • ;
  • a firework(s) display
    • ;
  • The firework spluttered and went out.
    • ;
  • They set off fireworks in their back garden.

column5: fairly hard; not easy to press into a different shape

column5: in a strong or definite way

• ‘I can manage,’ she said firmly.

column5: a sudden attack of an illness, such as epilepsy, in which somebody becomes unconscious and their body may make violent movements

• to have an epileptic fit

column5: a sports event that has been arranged to take place on a particular date and at a particular place

• There are plans to make the race an annual fixture.

column5: how food or drink tastes

  • in flavour It is stronger in flavour than other Dutch cheeses.

column5: a mistake in something that means that it is not correct or does not work correctly

• The argument is full of fundamental flaws.

column5: having a flaw; not perfect or correct

• seriously/fundamentally/fatally flawed

  • a flawed argument

  • the book’s flawed heroine

  • The study was methodologically flawed.
    • ;
  • a series of fatally flawed judgements

column5: to leave a person or place very quickly, especially because you are afraid of possible danger

• She burst into tears and fled.

column5: a group of military ships commanded by the same person

• a fleet of destroyers
    • ;
  • Nelson destroyed the Franco-Spanish fleet at the Battle of Trafalgar.

column5: the soft substance between the skin and bones of animal or human bodies
column10:
• The trap had cut deeply into the rabbit's flesh.
    • ;
  • Tigers are flesh-eating animals.

column5: the ability to change to suit new conditions or situations

column5: to develop quickly and become successful or common

• Few businesses are flourishing in the present economic climate.

  • The arts began to flourish at that time.

  • There was a flourishing black market.

column5: a liquid; a substance that can flow
column10:
• body fluids (= for example, blood)
    • ;
  • The doctor told him to drink plenty of fluids.

  • cleaning fluid

column5: having warm or loving feelings for somebody, especially somebody you have known for a long time
column10:
• Over the years, I have grown quite fond of her.

  • I’ve always been very fond of your mother.

column5: a person who you think behaves or speaks in a way that lacks intelligence or good judgement

• Don't be such a fool!

  • I felt a fool when I realized my mistake.

column5: part of a film showing a particular event

column5: to order somebody not to do something; to order that something must not be done

• forbid somebody (from doing something) He forbade them from mentioning the subject again.

  • Smoking is strictly forbidden.
    • ;
  • You cannot do that. I absolutely forbid it.

  • forbid somebody to do something You are all forbidden to leave.

  • forbid somebody something My doctor has forbidden me sugar.

  • forbid (somebody) doing something She knew her mother would forbid her going.

column5: a statement about what will happen in the future, based on information that is available now

• The sales forecasts are encouraging.

  • It is difficult to make long-term forecasts for a fast-growing industry.

  • The forecast said there would be sunny intervals and showers.
    • ;
  • The shipping forecast gave warnings of gales.

column5: to say what you think will happen in the future based on information that you have now
column10:
• forecast something Experts are forecasting a recovery in the economy.

  • Snow is forecast for tomorrow.

  • It is difficult to forecast the demand for the new train service.

  • forecast something to do something Temperatures were forecast to reach 40°C.
    • ;
  • forecast that… The report forecasts that prices will rise by 3% next month.

  • forecast how, what, etc… It is difficult to forecast how the markets will react.

column5: a person who comes from a different country
column10: • The fact that I was a foreigner was a big disadvantage.

column5: to put a lot of effort into making something successful or strong so that it will last

• a move to forge new links between management and workers

  • Strategic alliances are being forged with major European companies.

  • They forged a lead in the first 30 minutes of the game.

column5: the action of forming something; the process of being formed
column10:
• the formation of a new government
    • ;
  • evidence of recent star formation in the galaxy

column5: in the past
column10:
• Namibia, formerly known as South West Africa
    • ;

column5: a series of letters, numbers or symbols that represent a rule or law

column5: to create or prepare something carefully, giving particular attention to the details
column10:
• formulate something to formulate a policy/theory/plan/proposal
    • ;
  • The compost is specially formulated for pot plants.
    • ;
  • formulate something to do something This new kitchen cleaner is formulated to cut through grease and dirt.

column5: away from a place; out
column10:
• They set forth at dawn.
    • ;

• the forthcoming elections

column5: having or bringing an advantage, an opportunity, a piece of good luck, etc.

• Remember those less fortunate than yourselves.

  • fortunate to do something I have been fortunate enough to visit many parts of the world as a lecturer.

  • fortunate in having… I was fortunate in having a good teacher.

  • it is fortunate (for somebody) (that…) It was very fortunate for him that I arrived on time.

column5: an event or medium where people can exchange opinions and ideas on a particular issue; a meeting organized for this purpose
column10:
• forum (on something) to hold an international forum on drug abuse

  • forum for something Television is now an important forum for political debate.

column5: the parts of a dead animal or a plant that have become hard and turned into rock
column10: • fossils over two million years old

column5: to encourage something to develop

column5: a principle, an idea or a fact that something is based on and that it grows from

• Respect and friendship provide a solid foundation for marriage.

  • He laid the foundation of Japan's modern economy.

  • These stories have no foundation (= are not based on any facts).

  • without foundation The rumour is totally without foundation (= is not based on any facts).

column5: a person who starts an organization, institution, etc. or causes something to be built

• the founder and president of the company
    • ;
  • a wife and husband who are joint founders of the company

column5: a small part or amount of something
column10:
• Only a small fraction of a bank's total deposits will be withdrawn at any one time.

  • She hesitated for the merest fraction of a second.
    • ;

• fragile china/glass/bones

  • Be careful not to drop it; it’s very fragile.

column5: a small part of something that has broken off or comes from something larger

• fragment (of something) Police found fragments of glass near the scene.

  • in fragments The shattered vase lay in fragments on the floor.

column5: the parts of a building or an object that support its weight and give it shape
column10:
• built on a wooden framework
    • ;

column5: formal permission given by a company to somebody who wants to sell its goods or services in a particular area; formal permission given by a government to somebody who wants to operate a public service as a business

column5: in an honest and direct way that people might not like

column5: happening or doing something often

• He is a frequent visitor to this country.

column5: feeling annoyed and impatient because you cannot do or achieve what you want

• It's very easy to get frustrated in this job.

  • His apathy just made her even more frustrated.

column5: to do or achieve what was hoped for or expected
column10: • to fulfil your dream/ambition/potential

column5: for all the hours of a week during which people normally work or study, rather than just for a part of it

• students in full-time education

  • a full-time job
    • ;
  • Looking after a child is a full-time job (= hard work that takes a lot of time).

  • She works full-time and still manages to run a home.

column5: for all the hours of a week during which people normally work or study, rather than just for a part of it
column10:
• students in full-time education
    • ;
  • a full-time employee
    • ;
  • a full-time job
    • ;
  • Looking after a child is a full-time job (= hard work that takes a lot of time).
    • ;
  • She works full-time and still manages to run a home.

column5: practical and useful; with little or no decoration
column10:
• Bathrooms don't have to be purely functional.
    • ;
  • The office was large and functional rather than welcoming.

column5: in every way that is important; completely

column5: the activity of collecting money for a charity or organization, often by organizing social events or entertainments

column5: a ceremony, often a religious one, for burying or cremating (= burning) a dead person

    • ;

column5: very angry

• Their incompetence made me furious.

  • furious at something/somebody She was absolutely furious at having been deceived.

  • furious with somebody/yourself He was furious with himself for letting things get so out of control.
    • ;
  • furious that… I'm furious that I wasn't told about it.

column5: a unit for measuring liquid. In the UK, Canada and other countries it is equal to about 4.5 litres; in the US it is equal to about 3.8 litres. There are four quarts in a gallon.
column10: • The tankers carried 130 000 gallons of fuel.

column5: the activity of playing games of chance for money and of betting on horses, etc.

• online/internet gambling
    • ;

column5: a meeting of people for a particular purpose

column5: based on or connected with an ideology

• ideological differences

column5: a lack of knowledge or information about something

column5: a false idea or belief, especially about somebody or about a situation

• under the illusion that… She's under the illusion that (= believes wrongly that) she'll get the job.

  • illusion about something The new president has no illusions about the difficulties facing her country (= she knows that the country has serious problems).

  • I have no illusions about her feelings for me (= I know the truth is that she does not love me).

column5: language that produces pictures in the minds of people reading or listening

column5: extremely large or great

  • To my immense relief, he didn’t notice my mistake.

column5: the process of coming to live permanently in a different country from the one you were born in; the number of people who do this

• legal/illegal immigration

  • immigration policy/reform

column5: that cannot catch or be affected by a particular disease or illness

column5: the act of making something that has been officially decided start to happen or be used
column10: • the implementation of the new system

column5: a possible effect or result of an action or a decision

• They failed to consider the wider implications of their actions.

  • implication (of something) for something The development of the site will have implications for the surrounding countryside.

column5: to put somebody in a prison or another place from which they cannot escape
column10:
• be imprisoned (for something) They were imprisoned for possession of drugs.

  • be imprisoned (+ adv./prep.) (figurative) Some young mothers feel imprisoned in their own homes.

column5: the act of putting somebody in a prison or another place from which they cannot escape; the state of being there
column10: • to be sentenced to life imprisonment for murder

column5: the fact of not being able to do something

column5: not enough; not good enough

• inadequate supplies

  • inadequate for something The system is inadequate for the tasks it has to perform.

  • inadequate to do something The food supplies are inadequate to meet the needs of the hungry.

column5: something that encourages you to do something

• There is no incentive for people to save fuel.

column5: the extent to which something happens or has an effect

column5: wanting to do something

• She was inclined to trust him.

column5: the fact of including somebody/something; the fact of being included

column5: to include something so that it forms a part of something

• incorporate something The new car design incorporates all the latest safety features.

• incorrect information/spelling

column5: freedom from political control by other countries

column5: a list of names or topics that are referred to in a book, etc., usually arranged at the end of a book in alphabetical order or listed in a separate file or book

• Look it up in the index.

column5: a remark or sign that shows that something is happening or what somebody is thinking or feeling

column5: a sign that shows you what something is like or how a situation is changing

  • indigenous land/territory

column5: to persuade or influence somebody to do something

column5: to allow yourself to have or do something that you like, especially something that is considered bad for you

column5: as is certain to happen

a person or an animal that lives in a particular place

• instruct somebody to do something The letter instructed him to report to headquarters immediately.

• an integrated programme of patient care

• The aim is to promote closer economic integration.

column5: the act of getting involved in and trying to influence a situation that should not really involve you, in a way that annoys other people

• interference (in something) They resent foreign interference in the internal affairs of their country.

column5: located between two places, things, states, etc.

column5: very interesting because of being unusual or not having an obvious answer

column5: in a way that shows that you really mean the opposite of what you are saying; in a way that expresses irony

column5: to completely fill your mind so that you cannot think of anything else, in a way that is not normal

column5: the state in which a person’s mind is completely filled with thoughts of one particular thing or person in a way that is not normal

column5: a situation, an event, etc. that makes it difficult for you to do or achieve something

column5: something that you do in order to make somebody suffer because they have made you suffer
