• revenge for something She is seeking revenge for the murder of her husband.
    • ;
  • The bombing was an act of revenge for the shooting of two young boys.
    • ;
  • in revenge for something The bombing was in revenge for the assassination.
    • ;
  • revenge on somebody/something He swore to take (his) revenge on his political enemies.
    • ;
  • revenge attacks/killings

column5: the money that a government receives from taxes or that an organization, etc. receives from its business
column10:
• The government is currently facing a shortfall in tax revenue.
    • ;
  • Advertising revenue finances the commercial television channels.
    • ;
  • a slump in oil revenues
    • ;
  • The company's annual revenues rose by 30%.

column5: opposite to what has been mentioned
column10:
• to travel in the reverse direction
    • ;
  • The winners were announced in reverse order (= the person in the lowest place was announced first).
    • ;
  • The experiment had the reverse effect to what was intended.
    • ;
  • One year later she made the same journey in the reverse direction.

column5: the opposite of what has just been mentioned
column10:
• This problem is the reverse of the previous one.
    • ;
  • Although I expected to enjoy living in the country, in fact the reverse is true.
    • ;
  • In the south, the reverse applies.
    • ;
  • It wasn't easy to persuade her to come—quite the reverse.
    • ;
  • If you tell children to do something, they will often do the exact reverse.

column5: to change something completely so that it is the opposite of what it was before
column10:
• Falling birth rates may reverse the trend towards early retirement.
    • ;
  • to reverse a procedure/process
    • ;
  • The government has failed to reverse the economic decline.
    • ;
  • It is sometimes possible to arrest or reverse the disease.

column5: a change or set of changes to something
column10: • He made some minor revisions to the report before printing it out.

column5: an improvement in the condition or strength of something
column10:
• the revival of trade
    • ;
  • an economic revival
    • ;
  • a revival of property values

column5: to become, or to make somebody/something become, conscious or healthy and strong again
column10:
• The flowers soon revived in water.
    • ;
  • The economy is beginning to revive.
    • ;
  • revive somebody/something The paramedics couldn't revive her.
    • ;
  • This movie is intended to revive her flagging career.
    • ;
  • Attempts to revive him failed.

column5: connected with political revolution
column10:
• a revolutionary leader
    • ;
  • revolutionary uprisings

column5: speech or writing that is intended to influence people, but that is not completely honest or sincere
column10:
• the rhetoric of political slogans
    • ;
  • Her speech was just empty rhetoric.
    • ;
  • His speech was dismissed as mere rhetoric by the opposition.

column5: very silly or unreasonable
column10:
• I look ridiculous in this hat.
    • ;
  • Don't be ridiculous! You can't pay £50 for a T-shirt!
    • ;
  • It was ridiculous that this should be so difficult to say.
    • ;
  • They ate and drank a ridiculous amount.

column5: a gun with a long barrel which you hold to your shoulder to fire
column10:
• a hunting rifle
    • ;
  • an assault rifle

column5: a situation in which a group of people behave in a violent way in a public place, often as a protest
column10:
• One prison guard was killed when a riot broke out in the jail.
    • ;
  • He was killed in the riots.
    • ;
  • Shortages eventually led to food riots.

column5: to tear something or to become torn, often suddenly or violently
column10:
• rip (something) I ripped my jeans on the fence.
    • ;
  • The flags had been ripped in two.
    • ;
  • The nail ripped a hole in my jacket.
    • ;
  • I heard the tent rip.
    • ;
  • rip something + adj. She ripped the letter open.

column5: involving the possibility of something bad happening
column10:
• Life as an aid worker can be a risky business (= dangerous).
    • ;
  • Even a very good company can be a risky investment if it is overvalued.
    • ;
  • It's far too risky to generalize from one set of results.

column5: a series of actions that are always performed in the same way, especially as part of a religious ceremony
column10:
• religious rituals
    • ;
  • She objects to the ritual of organized religion.

column5: competing with another person, company, thing, etc.
column10:
• a rival bid/claim/offer
    • ;
  • fighting between rival groups/factions
    • ;
  • He was shot by a member of a rival gang.

column5: a person, company or thing that competes with another in sport, business, etc.
column10:
• The two teams have always been rivals.
    • ;
  • Marlowe was Shakespeare's main rival at the beginning of his career.
    • ;
  • the company's nearest/closest rival in the business
    • ;
  • The two men were bitter rivals throughout their careers.
    • ;
  • This latest design has no rivals (= it is easily the best design available).
    • ;
  • rival for something She has no rivals for the job.
    • ;
  • rival to somebody/something Grand it may be, but this cathedral is no rival to the great cathedral of Amiens.

column5: to steal money or property from a person or place
column10:
• to rob a bank
    • ;
  • The tomb had been robbed of its treasures.
    • ;
  • The gang had robbed and killed the drugstore owner.

column5: the crime of stealing money or goods from a bank, shop, person, etc., especially using violence or threats
column10:
• armed robbery (= using a gun, knife, etc.)
    • ;
  • There has been a spate of robberies in the area recently.
    • ;
  • He was shot as he tried to foil a bank robbery.
    • ;
  • He already had a conviction for armed robbery.

column5: strong and healthy
column10:
• She was almost 90, but still very robust.
    • ;
  • He seems to be in robust (good) health.

column5: to move gently backwards and forwards or from side to side; to make somebody/something move in this way
column10:
• (+ adv./prep.) The boat rocked from side to side in the waves.
    • ;
  • She was rocking backwards and forwards in her seat.
    • ;
  • rock somebody/something (+ adv./prep.) He rocked the baby gently in his arms.

column5: a spacecraft in the shape of a tube that is driven by a stream of gases let out behind it when fuel is burned inside
column10:
• a space rocket
    • ;
  • The rocket was launched in 2007.
    • ;
  • The idea took off like a rocket (= it immediately became popular).

column5: a long straight piece of wood, metal or glass
column10:
• The concrete is reinforced with steel rods.
    • ;
  • I finally managed to fix the curtain rods above the windows.
    • ;
  • After the accident she had an operation to put strengthening rods in her legs.
    • ;
  • He heated the end of the iron rod.
    • ;
  • a glass fibre rod 2 or 3 mm in diameter

column5: an exciting, usually short, relationship between two people who are in love with each other
column10:
• a holiday romance
    • ;
  • They had a whirlwind romance.

column5: a flower with a sweet smell that grows on a bush with thorns (= sharp points) on its stems
column10:
• a bunch of red roses
    • ;
  • a rose bush/garden
    • ;
  • a climbing/rambling rose

column5: to move or turn around a central fixed point; to make something do this
column10:
• Stay well away from the helicopter when its blades start to rotate.
    • ;
  • rotate about/around something winds rotating around the eye of a hurricane
    • ;
  • rotate something Rotate the wheel through 180 degrees.

column5: the action of an object moving in a circle around a central fixed point
column10:
• the daily rotation of the earth on its axis
    • ;
  • the earth's rotation around the sun

column5: approximately but not exactly
column10:
• Sales are up by roughly 10 per cent.
    • ;
  • We live roughly halfway between here and the coast.
    • ;
  • They all left at roughly the same time.
    • ;
  • Roughly speaking, we receive about fifty letters a week on the subject.

column5: the state or process of being destroyed or severely damaged
column10:
• A large number of churches fell into ruin after the revolution.
    • ;
  • The house had been left to go to ruin.
    • ;
  • The terrorist attack had left the city in a state of ruin

column5: to damage something so badly that it loses all its value, pleasure, etc.
column10:
• The bad weather ruined our trip.
    • ;
  • That one mistake ruined his chances of getting the job.
    • ;
  • My new shoes got ruined in the mud.
    • ;
  • The crops were ruined by the late frost.

column5: an official decision made by somebody in a position of authority, especially a judge
column10:
• The court will make its ruling on the case next week.
    • ;
  • The company intends to appeal against the ruling that it was negligent.

column5: a piece of information, or a story, that people talk about, but that may not be true
column10:
• to start/spread a rumour
    • ;
  • rumour of something There are widespread rumours of job losses.
    • ;
  • rumour about something Some malicious rumours are circulating about his past.
    • ;
  • rumour that… I heard a rumour that they are getting married.
    • ;
  • Many of the stories are based on rumour.
    • ;
  • Rumour has it (= people say) that he was murdered.
    • ;
  • I thought she was leaving the company, but perhaps it may be just a rumour.

column5: to dismiss somebody from a job
column10: • She was sacked for refusing to work on Sundays.

column5: connected with God or a god; considered to be holy
column10:
• a sacred image/shrine/temple
    • ;
  • sacred music
    • ;
  • Cows are sacred to Hindus.

column5: the fact of giving up something important or valuable to you in order to get or do something that seems more important; something that you give up in this way
column10:
• The makers of the product assured us that there had been no sacrifice of quality.
    • ;
  • Her parents made sacrifices so that she could have a good education.
    • ;
  • to make the ultimate/supreme sacrifice (= to die for your country, to save a friend, etc.)

column5: to give up something that is important or valuable to you in order to get or do something that seems more important for yourself or for another person
column10:
• sacrifice something for somebody/something She sacrificed everything for her children.
    • ;
  • The designers have sacrificed speed for fuel economy.
    • ;
  • sacrifice something Would you sacrifice a football game to go out with a girl?
    • ;
  • sacrifice something to something In her writing, clarity is sometimes sacrificed to brevity.

column5: a person that the Christian Church recognizes as being very holy, because of the way they have lived or died
column10:
• St John
    • ;
  • St Valentine’s Day
    • ;
  • The children were all named after saints.

column5: used to emphasize that it is important to do something or when you are annoyed about something
column10:
• Do be careful, for goodness' sake.
    • ;
  • Oh, for heaven's sake!
    • ;
  • For pity's sake, help me!

column5: an official order that limits trade, contact, etc. with a particular country, in order to make it do something, such as obeying international law
column10:
• Trade sanctions were imposed against any country that refused to sign the agreement.
    • ;
  • The economic sanctions have been lifted.

column5: the good feeling that you have when you have achieved something or when something that you wanted to happen does happen; something that gives you this feeling
column10:
• to gain/get/derive satisfaction from something
    • ;
  • a look/smile of satisfaction
    • ;
  • with satisfaction She looked back on her career with great satisfaction.
    • ;
  • He had the satisfaction of seeing his book become a bestseller.
    • ;
  • She didn't want to give him the satisfaction of seeing her cry.
    • ;
  • The company is trying to improve customer satisfaction.
    • ;
  • He was enjoying all the satisfactions of being a parent.

column5: the right to influence something by giving your opinion before a decision is made
column10:
• say (in something) We had no say in the decision to sell the company.
    • ;
  • People want a greater say in local government.
    • ;
  • say on something The judge has the final say on the sentence.

column5: behaviour or an event that people think is morally or legally wrong and causes public feelings of shock or anger
column10:
• a series of sex scandals
    • ;
  • to cause/create a scandal
    • ;
  • The scandal broke (= became known to the public) in May.
    • ;
  • There has been no hint of scandal during his time in office.
    • ;
  • a promising career wrecked by scandal

column5: a situation in which a lot of people are anxious or frightened about something
column10:
• a health scare
    • ;
  • recent scares about pesticides in food
    • ;
  • a scare story (= a news report that spreads more anxiety or fear about something than is necessary)
    • ;
  • to cause a major scare
    • ;
  • scare tactics (= ways of persuading people to do something by frightening them)

column5: to frighten somebody
column10:
• scare somebody You scared me.
    • ;
  • it scares somebody to do something It scared me to think I was alone in the building.

column5: spread far apart over a wide area or over a long period of time
column10:
• a few scattered settlements
    • ;
  • sunshine with scattered showers
    • ;
  • Her family are scattered around the world.

column5: a description of how things might happen in the future
column10:
• Let me suggest a possible scenario.
    • ;
  • The worst-case scenario (= the worst possible thing that could happen) would be for the factory to be closed down.
    • ;
  • a nightmare scenario

column5: having doubts that a claim or statement is true or that something will happen
column10:
• She looked highly sceptical.
    • ;
  • sceptical about something I am sceptical about his chances of winning.
    • ;
  • sceptical of something The public remain sceptical of these claims.

column5: a person who knows a lot about a particular subject because they have studied it in detail
column10:
• a classical scholar
    • ;
  • He was the most distinguished scholar in his field.

column5: an amount of money given to somebody by an organization to help pay for their education
column10:
• She won a scholarship to study at Stanford.
    • ;
  • on a scholarship He went to drama school on a scholarship.

column5: the opportunity or ability to do or achieve something
column10:
• scope for something There's still plenty of scope for improvement.
    • ;
  • Her job offers very little scope for promotion.
    • ;
  • scope (for somebody) (to do something) The extra money will give us the scope to improve our facilities.
    • ;
  • within somebody's scope First try to do something that is within your scope.

column5: a mark, a cut or an injury made by scratching somebody’s skin or the surface of something
column10:
• Her hands were covered in scratches from the brambles.
    • ;
  • a scratch on the paintwork
    • ;
  • It's only a scratch (= a very slight injury).
    • ;
  • without a scratch He escaped without a scratch (= was not hurt at all).

column5: to rub your skin with your nails, usually because it is itching
column10:
• scratch something John yawned and scratched his chin.
    • ;
  • scratch (yourself) The dog scratched itself behind the ear.
    • ;
  • Try not to scratch.
    • ;
  • scratch at something She scratched at the insect bites on her arm.

column5: the act of showing a film or television programme
column10: • This will be the movie's first screening in this country.

column5: a thin pointed piece of metal like a nail with a raised spiral line (called a thread) along it and a line or cross cut into its head. Screws are turned and pressed into wood, metal, etc. with a screwdriver in order to fasten two things together.
column10:
• One of the screws is loose.
    • ;
  • Now tighten all the screws.

column5: to fasten one thing to another or make something tight with a screw or screws
column10:
• The bookcase is screwed to the wall.
    • ;
  • You need to screw all the parts together.
    • ;
  • Now screw down the lid.

column5: careful and complete examination
column10:
• Her argument doesn't really stand up to scrutiny.
    • ;
  • Foreign policy has come under close scrutiny recently.
    • ;
  • The documents should be available for public scrutiny.
    • ;
  • The situation is bound to come under the scrutiny of the public health authorities.

column5: an official design or mark, stamped on a document to show that it is real and carries the authority of a particular person or organization
column10: • The letter bore the president's seal.

column5: to close an envelope, etc. by sticking the edges of the opening together
column10:
• Make sure you've signed the cheque before sealing the envelope.
    • ;
  • a sealed bid (= one that is kept in a sealed envelope and therefore remains secret until all other bids have been received)

column5: not connected with spiritual or religious matters
column10:
• secular music
    • ;
  • We live in a largely secular society.

column5: a person who is trying to find or get the thing mentioned
column10:
• an attention/a publicity seeker
    • ;
  • seekers after the truth

column5: in a way that appears to be true but may in fact not be
column10:
• a seemingly stupid question
    • ;
  • a seemingly endless journey
    • ;
  • It was a seemingly impossible task.

column5: a part of something that is separate from the other parts or can be considered separately
column10:
• She cleaned a small segment of the painting.
    • ;
  • Lines divided the area into segments.
    • ;
  • The changes will affect only a small segment of the population.
    • ;
  • They divided the bone into equal segments.

column5: to take somebody/something in your hand suddenly and using force
column10:
• seize something from somebody She tried to seize the gun from him.
    • ;
  • seize somebody/something He seized her by the arm.
    • ;
  • She seized hold of my hand.

column5: not often
column10:
• He had seldom seen a child with so much talent.
    • ;
  • She seldom, if ever, goes to the theatre.
    • ;
  • They seldom watch television these days.
    • ;
  • (literary) Seldom had he seen such beauty.

column5: affecting or involving only a small number of people or things from a larger group
column10:
• the selective breeding of cattle
    • ;
  • selective strike action
    • ;
  • the socially selective nature of population changes

column5: a class at a university or college when a small group of students and a teacher discuss or study a particular topic
column10:
• Teaching is by lectures and seminars.
    • ;
  • a graduate seminar
    • ;
  • a seminar room

column5: a member of a senate
column10:
• Senator McCarthy
    • ;
  • She has served as a Democratic senator for North Carolina since 2009.

column5: a feeling that you get when something affects your body
column10:
• a tingling/burning sensation
    • ;
  • I had a sensation of falling, as if in a dream.

column5: the ability to understand other people’s feelings
column10:
• sensitivity to the needs of children
    • ;
  • She pointed out with tact and sensitivity exactly where he had gone wrong.

column5: a feeling or an opinion, especially one based on emotions
column10:
• the spread of nationalist sentiments
    • ;
  • This is a sentiment I wholeheartedly agree with.
    • ;
  • Public sentiment is against any change to the law.
    • ;
  • My sentiments exactly! (= I agree)

column5: the act of separating people or things; the state of being separate
column10:
• separation from somebody/something the state’s eventual separation from the federation
    • ;
  • separation between A and B the need for a clear separation between Church and State

column5: doing the same thing in the same way several times; done in the same way several times
column10:
• a serial rapist
    • ;
  • He is wanted for serial murder.
    • ;
  • Such people can be described as serial monogamists.

column5: a way of organizing something; a system
column10:
• I've only been here a couple of weeks and I don't really know the set-up.
    • ;
  • What’s the set-up in your family—who does the cooking?

column5: an official agreement that ends an argument between two people or groups
column10:
• to negotiate a peace settlement
    • ;
  • The management and unions have reached a settlement over new working conditions.
    • ;
  • an out-of-court settlement (= money that is paid to somebody or an agreement that is made to stop somebody going to court)

column5: a person who goes to live in a new country or region
column10: • Most of the settlers came from England.

column5: very badly or seriously
column10:
• severely disabled
    • ;
  • areas severely affected by unemployment
    • ;
  • The crops were severely damaged.

column5: the feelings and activities connected with a person’s sexual desires
column10:
• He was confused about his sexuality.
    • ;
  • male/female sexuality
    • ;
  • the psychology of human sexuality
    • ;
  • Her overt sexuality shocked cinema audiences.
    • ;
  • Victorian women were rarely allowed to express their sexuality.

column5: sexually attractive
column10:
• the sexy lead singer
    • ;
  • She looked incredibly sexy in a black evening gown.

column5: having the type of shape mentioned
column10:
• a huge balloon shaped like a giant cow
    • ;
  • almond-shaped eyes
    • ;
  • an L-shaped room

column5: an owner of shares in a company or business
column10:
• the major shareholders in the company
    • ;
  • Company shareholders approved the merger.
    • ;
  • He has attracted new and existing shareholders to invest in his company.
    • ;
  • He was voicing the concerns of ordinary shareholders.
    • ;
  • The government is still a majority shareholder in the industry.

column5: to suddenly break into small pieces; to make something suddenly break into small pieces
column10:
• shatter (into something) He dropped the vase and it shattered into pieces on the floor.
    • ;
  • The mirror shattered into a thousand pieces.
    • ;
  • the sound of shattering glass
    • ;
  • shatter something (into something) The explosion shattered all the windows in the building.

column5: to get rid of something that is no longer wanted
column10:
• The factory is shedding a large number of jobs.
    • ;
  • a quick way to shed unwanted pounds (= extra weight or fat on your body)
    • ;
  • Museums have been trying hard to shed their stuffy image.

column5: used to emphasize the size, degree or amount of something
column10:
• The area is under threat from the sheer number of tourists using it.
    • ;
  • We were impressed by the sheer size of the cathedral.

column5: ships in general or considered as a group
column10:
• The canal is open to shipping.
    • ;
  • international shipping lanes (= routes for ships)

column5: that offends or upsets people; that is morally wrong
column10:
• shocking behaviour
    • ;
  • shocking news
    • ;
  • It is shocking that they involved children in the crime.
    • ;
  • a shocking waste of money

column5: the part that grows up from the ground when a plant starts to grow; a new part that grows on plants or trees
column10:
• new green shoots
    • ;
  • bamboo shoots

column5: the land along the edge of the sea, the ocean or a lake
column10:
• a rocky/sandy shore
    • ;
  • to swim from the boat to the shore
    • ;
  • on the shore Rubbish of all sorts is washed up on the shore.
    • ;
  • on the shores of something a house on the shores of the lake
    • ;
  • off shore The ship was anchored off shore.

column5: lasting a short time; designed only for a short period of time in the future
column10:
• a short-term loan
    • ;
  • to find work on a short-term contract
    • ;
  • short-term plans
    • ;
  • a short-term solution to the problem
    • ;
  • His short-term memory (= the ability to remember things that happened a short time ago) is failing.

column5: a situation when there is not enough of the people or things that are needed
column10:
• food/housing/water shortages
    • ;
  • a shortage of funds
    • ;
  • There is no shortage of (= there are plenty of) things to do in the town.

column5: a short time; not long
column10:
• She arrived shortly after us.
    • ;
  • I saw him shortly before he died.
    • ;
  • I bought a new umbrella but lost it shortly afterwards.

column5: to become smaller, especially when washed in water that is too hot; to make clothes, cloth, etc. smaller in this way
column10: • My sweater shrank in the wash.

column5: to raise your shoulders and then drop them to show that you do not know or care about something
column10:
• Sam shrugged and said nothing.
    • ;
  • shrug something ‘I don't know,’ Anna replied, shrugging her shoulders.

column5: a brother or sister
column10:
• squabbles between siblings
    • ;
  • sibling rivalry (= competition between brothers and sisters)
    • ;
  • The younger children were badly treated by older siblings.
    • ;
  • poor relationships between siblings

column5: an act or the sound of sighing
column10:
• to give/heave/let out a sigh
    • ;
  • a deep sigh
    • ;
  • ‘I'll wait,’ he said with a sigh.
    • ;
  • We all breathed a sigh of relief when it was over.

column5: to take and then let out a long deep breath that can be heard, to show that you are disappointed, sad, tired, etc.
column10:
• He sighed deeply at the thought.
    • ;
  • sigh with something She sighed with relief that it was all over.

column5: your name as you usually write it, for example at the end of a letter
column10:
• Someone had forged her signature on the cheque.
    • ;
  • They collected 10 000 signatures for their petition.
    • ;
  • He was attacked for having put his signature to the deal.
    • ;
  • Can you witness my signature on my will, please?

column5: the importance of something, especially when this has an effect on what happens in the future
column10:
• a decision of major political significance
    • ;
  • The new drug has great significance for the treatment of the disease.
    • ;
  • They discussed the statistical significance of the results.
    • ;
  • We should be fully aware of the significance of television in shaping our ideas.

column5: to create particular conditions that exist in real life using computers, models, etc., usually for study or training purposes
column10:
• Computer software can be used to simulate conditions on the seabed.
    • ;
  • Role-playing is a useful way of simulating real-life situations.
    • ;
  • The device simulates conditions in space quite closely.

column5: a situation in which a particular set of conditions is created artificially in order to study or experience something that could exist in reality
column10:
• a computer simulation of how the planet functions
    • ;
  • a simulation model
    • ;
  • An important part of training is role-play and the simulation of court cases.

column5: at the same time as something else
column10:
• The game will be broadcast simultaneously on TV and radio.
    • ;
  • simultaneously with something The slowdown of the US economy occurred simultaneously with a downturn in Europe.

column5: an offence against God or against a religious or moral law
column10:
• to commit a sin
    • ;
  • Confess your sins to God and he will forgive you.
    • ;
  • God forgives our sins.
    • ;
  • The Bible says that stealing is a sin.

column5: in a particular place or position
column10:
• My bedroom was situated on the top floor of the house.
    • ;
  • The hotel is beautifully situated in a quiet spot near the river.
    • ;
  • All the best theatres and restaurants are situated within a few minutes' walk of each other.
    • ;
  • Zakro was well situated for trade with Greece.
    • ;
  • ideally situated for touring the country

column5: a simple picture that is drawn quickly and does not have many details
column10:
• The artist is making sketches for his next painting.
    • ;
  • She drew a sketch map of the area to show us the way.

column5: having enough ability, experience and knowledge to be able to do something well
column10:
• a skilled engineer/negotiator/craftsman
    • ;
  • a shortage of skilled labour (= people who have had training in a skill)

  • He subsequently became chairman of the party.

column5: money that is paid by a government or an organization to reduce the costs of services or of producing goods so that their prices can be kept low

column5: large in amount, value or importance

column5: very much; a lot

column5: a person or thing that you use or have instead of the one you normally use or have

column5: to take the place of somebody/something else; to use somebody/something instead of somebody/something else

column5: an act of using one person or thing in the place of another

• Two substitutions were made during the game.

  • substitution of A for B the substitution of low-fat spreads for butter

  • substitution of B with A the substitution of butter with low-fat spreads

column5: not very obvious or easy to notice

column5: an area where people live that is outside the centre of a city

column5: in or connected with a suburb

column5: a number of people or things that follow each other in time or order

column5: following immediately one after the other

column5: to take liquid, air, etc. into your mouth by using the muscles of your lips

column5: to make a claim against a person or an organization in court about something that they have said or done to harm you

• They threatened to sue if the work was not completed.

    • ;
  • He threatened to sue the company for negligence.

  • sue somebody/something The water authority was successfully sued over his illness.

column5: physical or mental pain

column5: enough for a particular purpose; as much as you need

column5: enough for a particular purpose; as much as you need

• We reached the summit at noon.

column5: extremely good

  • We had a super time in Italy.

column5: excellent; of very good quality

• a superb player

column5: better in quality than somebody/something else; greater than somebody/something else

• vastly superior

  • superior intelligence

column5: to be in charge of somebody/something and make sure that everything is done correctly, safely, etc.

• supervise (somebody/something) to supervise building work

column5: the work or activity involved in being in charge of somebody/something and making sure that everything is done correctly, safely, etc.

column5: a person who supervises somebody/something

column5: to add something to something in order to improve it or make it more complete

• supplement something with something a diet supplemented with vitamin pills

column5: encouraging somebody or giving them help or sympathy

• a supportive family
    • ;
  • She was very supportive during my father's illness.

column5: according to what is generally thought or believed but not known for certain

• The novel is supposedly based on a true story.

• the Supreme Commander of the armed forces

• She felt a sudden surge of anger.

  • a surge of excitement

column5: to move quickly and with force in a particular direction

• The gates opened and the crowd surged forward.

column5: an amount that is extra or more than you need

• food surpluses

  • in surplus Wheat was in surplus that year.

column5: to admit that you have been defeated and want to stop fighting; to allow yourself to be caught, taken prisoner, etc.

• The rebel soldiers were forced to surrender.

• The police are keeping the suspects under constant surveillance.

  • surveillance cameras/equipment

column5: the state of continuing to live or exist, often despite difficulty or danger

• an act of terrorism

column5: to make a statement that something happened or that something is true, especially as a witness in court

column5: a book that teaches a particular subject and that is used especially in schools and colleges

column5: the way a surface, substance or piece of cloth feels when you touch it, for example how rough, smooth, hard or soft it is

• the soft texture of velvet

column5: used to show that you are pleased that something good has happened or that something bad has been avoided

• a degree in theology

column5: quiet, because you are thinking

column5: to make a formal and serious promise to do something or a formal statement that is true

column5: the fact of being weak and easily hurt physically or emotionally

column5: weak and easily hurt physically or emotionally

column5: to walk slowly around or to a place, often without any particular sense of purpose or direction

• + adv./prep. She wandered aimlessly around the streets.

• warrant something Further investigation is clearly warranted.

  • weave (something) Most spiders weave webs that are almost invisible.

column5: during the time that something is happening; at the same time as something else is happening

• In the UK it is illegal to drive whilst holding a mobile phone.

• The terrace runs the full width of the house.

column5: the quality of being happy and ready to do something

column5: to rub something against a surface, in order to remove dirt or liquid from it; to rub a surface with a cloth, etc. in order to clean it

• wipe something (on something) Please wipe your feet on the mat.

column5: the ability to make sensible decisions and give good advice because of the experience and knowledge that you have
